descriptive.p: The Clinical Statement Pattern is renamed the Care Statement Structure in this Care Structure Topic in order to emphasize that Care may apply to medical devices, facilities, and environmental sites as well as patients. In that sense, the vocabulary used to support Care Statements is more extensive than the vocabulary used to support simply the care of patients. These extensions will be documented by a gradual increase in the number and variety of HL7 vocabulary value sets.

The intention is that a care statement instance may be added by itself to the Care Provision Act at creation of the RMIM or added at run-time execution of an application in order to support the variability of extent and detail described in the clinical statement definition above. Of course, the care statement may be added to the Care Provision Act along with adding the other structures of the Care Provision Domain as well.
The extension of clinical statement to care statement extends the definition of care statement to:

indent.p: An expression of a discrete item of care-related information that is recorded because of its relevance to the care of a target of care. Care information is fractal in nature and therefore the extent and detail conveyed in a single statement may vary.
To be regarded as a care statement, a concept must be associated with a target of care in a manner which makes clear:

list.item: Its temporal context
Its relationship to the target of care
In the case of an observation: its mood and presence, absence or value
In the case of a procedure: its mood and status

indent.p: This clarity may be achieved by

list.item: Explicit representation; or
Implicit application of defaults ONLY where explicitly modelled rules state the appropriate defaults.

descriptive.p: The reader should refer to the documentation for the HL7 Reference Information Model for a complete set of attribute descriptions for each class in the Care Statement Structure.

p.emph: 4.0.3.4.2 Constraints on the Clinical Statement Pattern Domain:

list.item: The multiplicity on Clinical Statement ActChoice Act identifiers is published in the Pattern as (0*), which is constrained in Care Statement Act identifiers to (1*). The reason for this important constraint is that the extensive use of ActReference and queries in the Care Provision Domain depends on the existence of instance identifiers. These instance identifiers normally have been generated by the system authoring the instance. However, many instance identifier strategies exist and the only assumption in this constraint is that an instance identifier uniquely identifies the instance in systems to be queried. Instances may be privately communicated from an originating system to a receiving system or interface engine which adds unique system identifiers and then re-sends the instances out to other systems. In this case, the original system cannot be queried. Only the systems that have generated or received unique instance identifiers can be queried.

Two constraints are added to specific Care Structures classes from the Infrastructure Root Class: InfrastructureRoot.realmCode; InfrastructureRoot.templateID. These constraints are intended to be used in Care Structures in the same way they are used in CDA Release 2 documents. That is, until more specific HL7 methods are agreed upon for templates, the template ID refers to a unique specification guide within a Care Provision Topic. The realmCode is then used to further constrain a template ID, giving different realms the ability to leverage a specific template in a unique way (especially by additional constraints on vocabulary usage). All of the Classes in the Care Statement include the templateId and realmCode attributes.

Care Structure Constraints: The Clinical Statement Pattern is very general and allows all clinical Statements (or in the case of this Topic, the "Care Statements) to be represented from recursions on the ClinicalStatement choice. However, in the Care Structure Topic, as a Care Structure derived from the Care Statement Pattern is unrolled and defined, the Care Statement is constrained from representing that same structure in the same RMIM. In other words, in the same RMIM, one must not represent concern events both in the Concern Tracking Structure and from Concern Acts constructed from the CareStatement. Therefore, the following Care Structures each act as a constraint on the Care Statement when the derived Care Structure and the Care Statement are used in the same RMIM.

descriptive.p: Over time, the Care Structures Topic will include additional Care Structures that may be used by specific realms for specific purposes with specific constraints on vocabulary through the use of the HL7 attributes, InfrastructureRoot.templateId and InfrastructureRoot.realmCode. In this way, constraints will be explicitly defined in both the unrolled portions of the structure and the remaining, constrained, Care Statement portion of the structure. Consequently, when the publication of templates is defined, many Care Structures published in this document may be re-classified and published as templates instead.

In the following section, the RMIM's for the specific Care Structures will be described. They will be described first in a "clinically relevant manner" in a general narrative. Following the general clinical narrative, there will be a formal walk-thru developed as found in a typical engineering specification. Not all of the formal walk-thru's have been completed for this ballot.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Assessment scales are becoming more and more common in healthcare. For many years, the APGAR scale has been used to evaluate a newborn immediately after birth. Another example is the Barthel index, used mostly by nursing. The aim of the Barthel Index is to be able to capture and follow the level of help required by the patient in the performance of activities of daily life. (Mahoney Barthel, 1965) 1 . The scientific validation for the Netherlands was carried out by de Haan et al (1993) 2 . It appears that the Dutch version of the scale is valid and reliable for individual use and for use in populations (epidemiological research), as a measure of outcome, for example. There are realm specific differences in the original English and the translated Dutch version of the scale, e.g. the value sets differ. The total score of the index depends on individual component scores on ten variables.

The model for the Barthel Index starts with the naming on top (entry-point), with the name Barthel_Index. Beneath that is the act type Observation(OBS) with the name Barthel_Index. This is the central OBS for this model. In this act the total score of the Barthel Index is shown. The class Barthel Index has class code = OBS. Furthermore, the field for code system should be filled with the Barthel Index. In the derivation code the total score for the Barthel Index is recorded. In other words: derivation method = add all values of the separate variables. Effective time is the point in time on which the Barthel Index is scored. In the value, which was created by adding the individual variables, is filled up. This is always an INT data type because it is mandatory to score and fill up all items to get a proper sum score. That is why Mandatory (1..1). Interpretationshows how the total score should be interpreted. This is 0-9 for seriously limited, 10-19 for moderately limited and 20 for independent.

The OBS Barthel_Index contains ten variables itself, which each contain another OBS. These are bowels, bladder, grooming, toilet use, feeding, transfers, mobility, dressing, stairs and bathing respectively. For each of them the scoring options of 0 up to 3 are given in the field ObservationMethod. The result of the score comes in to the field value. For all OBS the time can be recorded in effective time. In codea unique code is given for the concerning variable. In earlier versions ICF codes were used, however, these cause too much confusion with other similar observations of the patient one wants to record.

p.emph: Mahoney, F. I., and Barthel, D. (1965). Functional Evaluation: The Barthel Index. Maryland State Medical Journal, 14, 56-61.

Haan, de, R., Limburg, M., Schuling, J., Broeshart, J., Jonkers, L., and Zuylen, van, P., (1993). Klinimetrische evaluatie van de Barthel-index, een maat voor beperkingen in het dagelijks functioneren, Nederlands Tijdschrift voor Geneeskunde, 37 (18), 917-921.

descriptive.p: The current code set is temporarily for projects.

A formal walk-through will be developed. For now, the reader should refer to the documentation for the HL7 Reference Information Model for a complete set of attribute descriptions for each class in this RMIM.

rmim.name: Care Structures Event Cared Entity
rmim.descriptive:
Cared Entity Structure
The Cared Entity Structure supports a Maintained Entity as a participant of an Act played by a place or device. An example is a Care Provision Acts Subject participant being a patient's ambulatory device requiring repair or toxic waste needed to be removed from the patient's adjacent surroundings. MaintainedEntity
The role of the entity that is maintained. The maintained entity is played by either a place entity (E_Place, see description in CMET domain) or device entity (Device) and scoped by an Organization (Organization) that is responsible for maintaining the place or device. Attributes
classCode: The mandatory classCode is specified as MNT (maintained entity). id: set of identifiers that uniquely identifying the entity as part of its maintained role. code: a role code that further classifies the type of the maintained entity. name: a set of entity names by which the maintain entity is known. addr: a set of addresses where the maintained entity is located. Device
A device that is playing the role of Maintained Entity. The device may also play the role of located entity (LocatedEntity). Attributes
classCode: The mandatory class code is specified as DEV (EntityClassDevice), a specialization of Manufactured Material. determinerCode: The mandatory determiner code is specified as INSTANCE (specific).
id: set of identifiers that uniquely identifying the device independently from its maintained role.
desc: a multimedia representation or text description of the device. manufacturerModelName: a string or coded model name assigned by the device manufacturer. LocatedEntity
The role of device that is locatable at some address or place. The located entity is optionally scoped by a place entity (E_Place, see description in CMET domain). Attributes
classCode: The mandatory classCode is specified as LOCE (RoleClassLocatedEntity).
addr: a set of addresses where the device is located, to be used when a scoping Place entity is not provided.
effectiveTime: the interval of time that the device is located at the specified address or place Organization
An organisation that is scoping the role of Maintained Entity. Attributes
classCode: The mandatory class code is specified as ORG (EntityClassOrganization).
determinerCode: The mandatory determiner code is specified as INSTANCE (specific).
id: set of identifiers that uniquely identifying the maintaining organization. name: a set of organization names by which the maintaining organization is known.
telecom: a set of electronic communication numbers or addresses where the maintaining organization can be contacted.
addr: a set of addresses where the maintaining organization is located or contactable.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Concern List RMIM will move to a Working List Management Topic and other related messages when Patient Care creates this new topic.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: One particular feature of the Care Provision models and messages is the possibility to track the condition of the patient / target across time, providers and locations. In order to allow this within the mechanics of the HL7 v3 messaging, the Concern Act class is introduced and fully explained in this Concern Tracking Topic area of this ballot.

The Concern Tracking Structure supports the expression of concerns about situations pertaining to selected entities that are the target or subject of care. It organizes basic clinical data into a longitudinal data structure, which supports tracking and management of complex processes over time.

Definition of Concern Class as result of harmonization work: An interest or focus of attention that tends to persist over time and has as a subject a state or process. The subject of the interest or focus of attention has the potential to require intervention or management.

Concern tracking is used to implement the problem-oriented medical record concept introduced by Larry Weed in the 1960's and 1970's. For engineers, the problem-oriented medical record can be considered a health care version of industrial project management processes that focus on issue resolution. The intention of this model is to support both the tracking of these concerns at the "high-level" as well as the detailed tracking of complex management processes at the "low-level." The decision on whether to track concerns at the high-level or low-level is to be an application-dependent decision. Applications may use techniques described in this section to track concerns but are not required at this level of the specification to include all the tracking information.

Examples of use for the Concern Class include but are not limited to: an observation result in form of a diagnosis e.g. a patient having cancer which gives the concern a name, a procedure such as amputation of the left leg requiring care management, a substance administration, e.g. receiving cytotoxic drugs requiring extra management, equipment repair status, device recall status, a health risk, a financial risk, public health risk, pregnancy, disease, complaint. In particular this concern class is used to group information about, or to follow up on, a specific episode of care, or a care need or patient problem, especially if more than one provider is involved in the care.

In the usual course of presentation, diagnosis, and treatment, the caretaker of a concern gains a gradually better understanding of the concern. An example of a concern in the disease management area is the Episode of Illness.

In a typical clinical scenario, the patient presents to the clinician with the "chief complaint." This chief complaint or chief concern is one of many symptoms that represent the patient's view of the primary problem from which the patient is suffering. Multiple questions and exams are performed on the patient, which provides a data set from which a clinician may develop a viewpoint on the concern (the abductive or "hypothesis generating" phase of the process as described by Peirce). On the basis of this initial understanding of the concern, tests are ordered and observations carried out by the clinician and time passes. Frequently, the disease evolves and demonstrates more symptoms and signs. At each point in time during multiple contacts with the patient or with patient data, the clinician has evolved a set of potential diagnoses. In addition, during each point in time, various treatments may be recommended by the clinician, citing the concern as the reason for the various treatments.

One business need filled by the Concern Tracking Structure is to support the direct care of the patient with an organized model for representing multiple contacts with the subject of care while the concern is evolving, data is being collected, and treatments are being applied. In addition, the business needs of quality improvement and cost accounting performed by data mining applications are supported by tracking the evaluation and management actions associated with the concern.

Thus the concern class can function as a grouper for all activities associated with a specific patient-related problem. The problem can, due to different observations, evolve over time and can be tracked or managed by one or more care professionals. Different professionals may have different opinions of the nature of the problem, but all their observations are grouped under the same concern. So essentially, the concern class is used to track what affects the patient. It is independent of the assigned profession, and can have different personal diagnoses attached. It is what ties all underlying activities (Acts) together. See figure 1 for how some of these concerns can relate to each other:
Figure 1: different concerns for the same individual represented in time.

In the discussion that follows, the Concern Tracking Structure will be divided into four levels of function that support communications at differing levels of detail. These four levels of function include:

list.item: The attention for the Concern itself, i.e. the subject(s) of concern
Adding additional contextual information to the concern, i.e. references to additional relevant Care Statements
Using attention for a Concern to justify additional management, i.e. Concern as "Reason for an intervention"
Establishing associations with past instances of Concern in order to fully represent the Episode of Illness

descriptive.p: Guidance: In HL7, the Observation Class is used to communicate the perception of a state or process. These are linked together under a concern. In the RIM, the term Act always represents a record regarding the process of doing. Observation represents a constraint on the definition of Act that takes the form: the Act of Observation where Observation is the noun form of the infinitive "to observe." Therefore, the Act of Observation is also the recording of a process. In addition, Observation may need to be constrained further with various Act.code values in order to narrow the definition of the Act of Observation to various types of observation processes.

The "Attention" for a Concern is simply the idea or hypothesis that one of many potential states or processes may potentially require extra attention and management. The specific item or items of concern is represented as the "Subject or Subjects of Concern. At least one subject of concern must be present in a Concern Tracking Structure. In some implementation guides, the Subject Act Relationship may be constrained to one or a few subjects rather than a large or infinite number of subjects. All subjects of concern should be considered as a single cluster or focus of concern. A patient may have multiple concerns identified, each with a collection of subjects.

In healthcare, the concern for the medical device, home of the patient, or other non-living subjects may need to be managed as well as the concern for the patients' bodies and wellbeing themselves. Accordingly, "concern " in this discussion is meant to be a general term referring to state of being of any entity.
The key characteristics of this Concern Act class are that it allows to link different stages in the condition of the patient / target in the following ways:

list.item: It might be possible that one patient has two different concerns that normally are unrelated; however, there might be interactions. Example: a patient with diabetes that has an accident and breaks a leg. It is not due to any diabetes related problem. Thus there will be two separate concern trackers: one for the diabetes care, another for the treatment of the fracture. Basically from the Concern Act point of view these are unrelated. In terms of instantiation of classes: the Concern Act is instantiated one time for diabetes and will get an unique class ID, and the Concern Act is instantiated a second time for the fracture and gets another - different - class ID.

It might occur that a patient has a concern and within the care for that, there is a sub-concern, requiring special attention, related to the top-level concern. For instance a woman being pregnant (the top-level concern) who has high blood pressure (the sub-concern). A similar example would be the Concern 'Obesities' for a patient and related to this the sub concern of (risk for) Diabetes type II. We apply the Component Act relationship in the Concern Tracker structure for this. In addition, a use case frequently occurring is to refer to a fetus' observations, e.g. fetal heart rate, but it goes in the record and messages of the pregnant woman. In that instance, the Condition of mother (patient) is pregnant, which must be linked to the sub Condition of fetus is 'unborn' and the underlying observation of the fetal heart rate. In the COMP actRelationship, the Id of the 'Concern' and that of the 'sub-Concern' are separate and independent, and simply linked in a parent-child actRelationship.

Some concerns exist during a period, go away for a while and come back later. Basically the concern is intermittent in nature, although the concern-related observations and diagnoses of the patient might change over time. Examples include the exacerbation of COPD, or the 'winter blues'. We can apply the Sequel (SEQL) Act Relationship for this kind of linkage between concerns. Also this relationship is typically used to refer to an earlier pregnancy (Concern 1) during a current pregnancy (Concern 2). The concern ID's differ, but tackle a similar concern. In addition, the naming (Annotation) or underpinning (Observations) can have the same names, or values.

A concern might be the situation of the patient that evolves over time and about which different providers involved (including the patient him/herself) have matured their insight. For example a patient talking about chest pain, a general practitioner thinking about a cardiac problem, and the cardiologist diagnosing a myocardial infarction. In particular relevant is also the example of episodes of pregnancy, delivery and maternity. ELNK is intended to link different parts (episodes or periods, sometimes with different care providers and care provisions) of the same concern: e.g., link pregnancy to delivery and to maternity. The concern tracker structure allows grouping of observations, procedures, encounters, and other acts for the particular concern, and this grouping can contain different diagnoses of different providers, all associated with the same concern. Thus, the concern is a patient-related grouper, which can be used throughout the whole care provision if the care is carried out by one professional, or to several care provisions if the care is performed by several professionals. In the above example the general practitioner has provided care and probably referred the patient to the cardiologist. The cardiologist starts his Care Provision but this can be grouped under the same concern. The test results obtained by the Cardiologist also go under this concern, thus maturing the insight in the problem the patient has. This can be dealt with using the ELINK Episode link Act Relationship, where the id for the concern class remains the same over time, but the Act ids for the different episodes (patient himself, general practitioner, cardiologist) can differ. In the ELINK actRelationship, each Concern' has a separate and unique identifier.

descriptive.p: In particular two options: the merge and split of acts are relevant here. It might be that initially two concerns have been treated as separate instances, but need to merge into one concern. For example, evolving insights might lead to the conclusion that one was a symptom concern of the other being a disease concern. In such example the symptom concern can be grouped under the disease concern by replacing the ID of the symptom concern with the one of the disease concern. This can be done with the ELINK relationship Similarly, if two interest, initially grouped under the same Concern (with the same ID), appear to be independent of each other, then the two concerns can be split, where best is to give each a new instance identifier, or allow one concern to be continued under the same concern ID, and the split concern getting a new ID. This is dealt with using the Replace relationship.

These four linkage types: Component, Sequel, Episode Link and Replace are considered the use cases that are dealt with in detail in this Concern Tracking Topic. Further, there is an explanatory document attached to the Care Provision ballot materials covering much more detail and examples.

References from Concern to other Care Statements: The use of the "Reference ActRelationship" from the Concern to a Care Statement Choice Box (represented here as A_CareStatement CMET) allows the clinician to identify additional Care Statements that may be relevant to the "context of the Concern," but which cannot be truly classified as subjects of the concern. A normal lab result is an example. This "Reference ActRelationship" is especially helpful in communicating the context of the concern during the initial identification of the concern, i.e. the abductive or "hypothesis-generating" phase. Occasionally, "Reference" may be used to add important contextual information to the Concern as the understanding about the concern evolves.

Reasons for Management Actions: The "Reason ActRelationship" is used to cite the Concern as the reason for the management action. After the nature of the Concern is established by utilizing the Subject and Reference ActRelationships, most ActRelationships associated with Concern will be used to justify the services generated to address or manage the Concern. This ActRelationship is the "Reason ActRelationship" from Care Statements back to the instance of Concern itself.

Extending and Clarifying the Episode of Illness: Finally, there may be a need to identify associations to other instances of the same concern. For example, after treating a concern for a period of time, a physician may discover that another physician has been treating the same concern in another institution. In this case, the first physician may wish to simply link his concern to the other physician's concern, i.e. using "EpisodeLink ActRelationship;" or he may wish to ask the other physician to obsolete the other physician's concern using the "Replace ActRelationship."

Updating the Concern Tracking Structure: Note that the specific use cases and recommendations for update semantics and instance management in general are still being developed by M&M. Consequently, specific guidance regarding the use or change of the Replace and EpisodeLink ActRelationships may evolve as HL7 as a whole nails down the details of instance management.
Participations on the Concern Class: The participations on the Concern Class and the Care Statement Choice Boxes are the same participations defined for the Care Provision Domain in general.

emph.emph: Formal Concern Tracking Structure Model Walkthrough:

tr.td:
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =CONC
Note: until CONC is approved by M&M, ACT will be used instead of CONC

A mandatory attribute constrained to Concern (CONC), which is a subclass of Act. The definition of this class describes the "Being concerned or worried about a state or process..." (remaining definition to be crafted).
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=ActMood

A mandatory attribute which is constrained to the values in the ActMood. Normally, this will be constrained to EVN in many derived RMIM's, HMD's, and implementation guides. However, determinations of Concerns may be requested with RQO, or appointments may be scheduled with APPT
Immutable: Yes Optionality: (0...*) Datatype: SET<ii> Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable

A required attribute that shall be present if known; multiple id's may be present. Updates may add id's to the set, but may not change an id. This attribute should be constrained to be present in most implementation guides.
Immutable: No Optionality: * (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=ActStatusCode

A required attribute that shall be present and shall be valued with a NullFlavor or with members of a value set bound to the Vocabulary Domain "ActStatusCode." This attribute is used to define whether the concern of a performer:
new - draft (not messaged, we use these internally though)
active - currently being concerned
completed - resolved concern
aborted - a concern which we decide to drop without resolution
suspended - a concern which is active but we are setting it aside
nullified - a concern which was created in error
obsolete - a concern which has been replaced by another concern
Updates in the value of the attribute are allowed.
Immutable: No Optionality: * (0...1) Datatype: IVL<GTS> Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable

A required attribute constrained to the time range the concern was active or suspended is or was present in the subject if known. If still present at time of update, only the low value in the time range is expressed.
Immutable: No Optionality: * (0...1) Datatype: CV Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=Confidentiality

A required attribute that may be present and shall be valued with NullFlavor or members of a value set bound to the Vocabulary Domain "Confidentiality." Updates in the value of the attribute are allowed.

td.p: typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =SUBJ

A mandatory attribute constrained to SUBJ, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to identify the subjects of concern (a care statement). At least one subject of concern must be present. All the subjects of concern must be related to each other as if in "a cluster of items which together constitute a concern."
contextControlCode
Immutable: No Optionality: * (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=AN
A required attribute that shall be present and shall be valued with NullFlavor or AN. Updates in the value of the attribute are allowed.
contextConduction-Ind
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: BL Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable
A mandatory attribute that shall be valued with a Boolean.
priorityNumber
Immutable: No Optionality: (0...1) Datatype: INT Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable

An optional attribute that shall be present when there is more than one subject of concern. The value set shall range from 1...* unless constrained by the implementation guide. The interpretation of the value is simply the listing order of the subjects of concern where for the first subject of concern, INT = 1.
Constrained Attribute Description
typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=REFR

A mandatory attribute constrained to REFR, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to establish a non-specific reference relationship to any care statement. The ActRelationship itself is optional and is normally used only when the author feels a care statement reflects the context of concern, but cannot truly be called "a subject of concern."
contextControlCode
Immutable: No Optionality: * (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=AN

A required attribute that shall be present and shall be valued with NullFlavor or AN. Updates in the value of the attribute are allowed. "Context" in this attribute refers to Participations of the Act and not to other associations often considered "Context".
contextConduction-Ind
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: BL Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable
A mandatory attribute that shall be valued with a Boolean. "Context" in this attribute refers to Participations of the Act and not to other associations often considered "Context"

descriptive.p: Clone Name: CareStatementChoiceBox (as A_CareStatement CMET)

td.p: Note that choice boxes constrain implementation guide developers to a set of Act clones from which to create ActRelationships.
See the Care Statement Structure for the formal walkthrough of this ChoiceBox.
subject1
This Care Statement Choice Box is constrained to contain only the choices of Observation, Procedure, and Substance Administration and NOT the choices of Supply, Encounter, and Generic Act
reference
This Care Statement Choice Box is unconstrained.
typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=RSON
A mandatory attribute constrained to RSON, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to establish justification for any care statement. The ActRelationship itself is optional.
contextControlCode
Immutable: No Optionality: * (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =AN
Refer to the RIM for description of this attribute.
contextConduction-Ind
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: BL Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable
Refer to the RIM for description of this attribute.
typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =SUBJ

A mandatory attribute constrained to SUBJ, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to add comments to the Concern when the Concern is the target of the optional AnnotationAct.
contextControlCode
Immutable: No Optionality: * (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =AN
Refer to the RIM for description of this attribute.
contextConduction-Ind
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: BL Vocabulary Domain: Not Applicable
Refer to the RIM for description of this attribute.
Attribute

A mandatory attribute constrained to SUBJ, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to document change in status of a Concern, such as going from "Being Concerned (status='active' )" to "No longer concerned (status = 'completed')".

descriptive.p: Clone Name: links .

td.p: typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =ELNK

A mandatory attribute constrained to ELNK, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to string together the instances of Concern without changing the statusCode of the target Concern Act to "obsolete." Use ReplaceCONC if the target Concern is to become obsolete.
typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE =RPLC

A mandatory attribute constrained to RPLC, which is a type of ActRelationship. This ActRelationship is used to string together the instances of Concern when the statusCode of the target Concern Act is to be changed to "obsolete." Use LinksCONC if the target Concern is NOT to become obsolete.
Attribute

typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=COMP
The component relationship has a source of Concern and a target that is another Concern, and is used to create groupings of Concerns in a more or less hierarchical order.
Attribute

typeCode
Immutable: Yes Optionality: B* (1...1) Datatype: CS Vocabulary Domain: CNE <=SEQL
An act relationship indicating that the source Concern act follows the target Concern act.

rmim.name: Care Structures Event Statement
rmim.descriptive:
Care Statement Structure Overview:
The Care Statement Structure assists in collecting clinical information that can be documented during care provision. The choice box allows expressing any collection of statements about care in any order or number, and in any kind of combination, depending on the purpose and nature of the message.
The Care Statement Structure is the model from which all other Care Structures are derived. This derivation occurs by constraint. Based on the Clinical Statement Pattern, it is renamed the Care Statement Structure in this Domain Message Information Model for Care Provision in order to emphasize that Care may apply to medical devices, facilities, and environmental sites as well as patients. In that sense, the vocabulary used to support Care Statements is more extensive than the vocabulary used to support simply the care of patients. These extensions will be documented by a gradual increase in the number and variety of HL7 vocabulary value sets. This description does not replicate the full details of the Clinical Statement Pattern but documents those aspects that differ significantly from the base pattern.
The intention is that a care statement instance may be added by itself to the Care Provision Act at creation of the RMIM or added at runtime execution of an application in order to support the variability of extent and detail described in the care statement definition above. Of course, the care statement may be added to the Care Provision Act along with adding the other structures of the Care Provision Domain as well.
Use of the model
The Care Statement model represents a standard, high-level structure for the inclusion of clinical information in Care Provision communications intended to support specific business functions. Although not intended to be implemented 'as is', the Care Statement model can be constrained to meet the requirements of many specific communications regarding clinical information.
Options for pattern constraint include:
The generic 'Care Statement' class attributes may be constrained to reflect the precise nature of the data to be conveyed. For example:
Optional attributes may be removed if not appropriate to the business case.
Attributes themselves may be constrained:
multiplicities may be constrained to narrower number sets, e.g. (0..*) may be constrained to (1..*)
attribute value sets may be constrained to smaller attribute value sets, e.g. 'mood code' limited to 'Event'
Data types for an attribute may be constrained, e.g. 'ANY to CD'
Associations may be constrained to remove the potential for complexity, e.g. the limitation of an implementation to three levels of nesting; the removal of 'Episode Link' in order to define an implementation to the 'lowest common denominator' regarding system capabilities
Classes may be constrained:
Classes may be removed if not required
Classes may be constrained to specific subclasses, e.g. 'Observation Class' constrained to 'Vital signs Class'
Classes may be 'cloned' in order to document specific constraints on attributes or associations.
Classes with specific constraints applied may be 'unrolled' from the Clinical Statement Choice box in order to constrain their use to a specific structure (in that case, the constrained version of the class may no longer be assumed to be present in the generalized Care Statement Choice Box)
Classes may be combined into specific clinical artifacts, such as combined observations in case of blood pressure or clinical scales such as Apgar score and Barthel index.
This model is referenced by an Act external to the Care Statements. Often, this external Act provides the 'Entry point' to a communication specification and represents the context in which the care statement information is being sent. For example, the information regarding who is sending this information is found in an Act external to the Care Statements. The Care Provision Act in the Care Provision Domain is an example of an Act external to the Care Statement.
Care Statement Model (REPC_RM000100)Description
Model Overview
The model can be divided into 3 related parts: * CareEntry Choice Box * Participations surrounding the Acts * Acts outside the CareEntry Choice Box
CareEntry Choice Box
This part of the model is used to convey the detailed care statements that are being sent in support of the specific business need. As well as providing a mechanism for conveying the components of this information, it supports grouping of these components and provides mechanisms to explicitly link statements where there is a specific relationship.
The class clones in the CareEntry choice are the same as those available in the Clinical Statement Pattern ActChoice. Class clone names and all aspects of the attributes are identical.
Linking of Statements
The modeling of the linking of Care Statements has been modified from that in the Clinical Statement Pattern as follows:
The sourceOf / targetOf relationship has been unwrapped into 2 separate relationships: sourceOf and targetOf.
The target of the new sourceOf relationship is the outer CareStatement choice
sourceOf1 has been removed
A constraint has been added to the new sourceOf relationship stating that the value of contextConductionInd must be "false" if the target is an ActReference (context cannot be conducted to ActReferences)
This revised modeling approach provides the same semantics as that in the Clinical Statement Pattern but is considered to be a less complicated approach.
Record Target and Subject
As well as applying to a patient, a Care Statement can also apply to a variety of other types of entity (eg. Equipment). To support this, the target of the RecordTarget participation is a choice of the R_CarePatient and R_CaredEntity CMETs.
Similarly, the subject of a Care Statement can be any one of several types of entity including:
the patient
another person
a specimen
a device
a facility
an environmental site
An extended set of roles in the SubjectChoice that is the target of the subject participation supports this requirement. consumable
The consumable participation is used to bring in the Consumable Choice. This can be a Manufactured Product role (played by a Labelled Drug or a Material) or an Instance of Kind role (played by a Material Kind that can itself be specified as part of a larger whole).

rmim.name: Care Structures Event Statement Collector
rmim.descriptive:
Statement Collector Structure
The Statement Collector Structure is intended to support various methods of organizing Care Statements. A minimum of semantic information is implied by each organizing structure. However, the implications of these minimal semantics are very important to the policies and procedures of many organizations which may use templateId and realmCode attributes to specify additional semantics.
The Statement Collector is a choice of collector Acts, ActList and ActCategory. The Component (COMP) Act Relationship is used to group Care Statements into working lists and category lists created for specific purposes and applications. The structure can represent any kind of list or grouping used in Patient Care, e.g. problems, medications, allergies, observations, activities, encounters, and variances. Each collector Act may have an Author.
ActList
The ActList is a clone of the WorkingList Act, which has the following definition:
"A dynamic list of individual instances of Act which reflects the needs of an individual worker, team of workers, or an organization to view groups of Acts for clinical and administrative reasons." Examples include problem lists, goal lists, allergy lists, and to-do lists.
The ActList represents the myriad of dynamic or managed lists found in clinical summaries such as concern lists (e.g. problem lists or allergy lists), medication lists, surgery lists, etc.
The most common uses of working lists include lists managed at the departmental level. For example, it is common in many hospital organizations for the pharmacy department to create the medication list that is used for formal medication interaction applications when a new medication is added to the list. Another example of a departmental working list is the episode of care defined by the cost accounting department for analysis of the costs related to encounters that include a specific diagnosis. In this case, the ActList collects encounters that include Act Relationships to the specific concern. ActList Attributes
classCode: The mandatory classCode is specified as LIST (working list), a specialization of the Act class. moodCode: The mandatory moodCode used in ActList is always EVN (event).
code: This required attribute describes a kind of WorkingList. The ActListCode vocabulary domain provides a small set of coded values but this attribute allows extensions to this value set.
effectiveTime: The effectiveTime attribute is optional and represents the time interval for which the working list is active.ownershipLevelCode:
ActCategory
The formal definition of Category, which is a subclass of Organizer, is:
A group of entries within a composition or topic that have a common characteristic for example, Examination, Diagnosis, Management or Subjective, Objective, Analysis, Plan (SOAP).
The distinction from Topic, another subclass of Organizer relates to value sets. For Category there is a bounded list of things like "Examination", "Diagnosis" or SOAP categories. For Topic the list is wide open to any clinical concern or reason for a part of an encounter.
The ActCategory allows Care Statements to be classified externally to the Care Statement. For example, a particular template for a summary report may require the inclusion of data within specific, required categories. This external classification scheme for clinical statements supports that requirement. This mechanism allows a positive statement that "there is no content for this classification" within the pertinent information of Care Provision. ActCategory Attributes
classCode: The mandatory classCode is specified as CATEGORY, a specialization of the Organizer class under the abstract ActClassContainer sub-domain. moodCode: The mandatory moodCode used in the ActCategory is always EVN (event).
code: This required attribute describes a kind of Category. There is currently no vocabulary domain specified for this attribute. effectiveTime: The effectiveTime attribute represents the time interval for which the working list is active.
StatementCollector Associations
The StatementCollector choice has two associations:
Author Participation
Component Act RelationshipAuthor
The author of the StatementCollector is an Assigned Person, defined via the CMET R_AssignedPerson. The R_AssignedPerson CMET records the person who is responsible for providing the data in the list.
Attributes typeCode: The mandatory type code is AUT (author).
contextControlCode: Required attribute. See description provided in Common Participation Attributes of the DMIM walkthrough. The default value is "OP" (overriding, propagating). noteText: Optional notes provided by author.
time: The required time attribute is the time the author signed or completed the care statement collection. modeCode: Optional attribute specifying how the author provide the information, e.g. verbally, electronically or hand written. Use any value from the ParticipationMode domain. The default value is 'ELECTRONIC'.
signatureCode: This required attribute specifies if the author has, is required or intends to attest to the care statement collection. Use the following values from the ParticipationSignature domain.
CodeDescription
I (intended) The author intends to provide a signature.
S (signed) Signature has been affixed, either written on file, or electronic (incl. digital) signature in signatureText.
X (required)A signature for the care provision act is required of this author.
signatureText: Optional digital signature or multimedia representation of the signature provided by the author, attesting to the care statement collection. Component
The StatementCollector is composed of a list of Care Statements, specified using the Local CMET A_CareStatement. The A_CareStatement structure supports the recording of any care statement, its structure is described in the Care Statement section.Attributes
typeCode: The mandatory type code is COMP (component). contextControlCode: Required attribute. See description provided in Common ActRelationship Attributes section of the DMIM walkthrough. The default value is "AN" (additive, non-propagating).
contextConductionInd: Mandatory attribute. See description provided in Common ActRelationship Attributes section of the DMIM walkthrough. The default value is "true". sequenceNumber: The optional sequenceNumber attribute can be used to indicate the order of each component.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Typically, "vital signs" represent a collection of individual findings, each of which include a reference range. This reference range may be specific for the age or gender of the patient or other "patient criteria." In addition, the vital signs may be qualified by a specific state the patient is in, e.g. actively exercising; at rest; etc.

In this RMIM, the focal class identifies the entire collection of vital signs. The vital signs are taken after the state of the patient is noted, as indicated by the "startsAfterStartOf" ActRelationship. Finally, the component vital signs, the respective reference range for each vital sign, and the criterion for each reference range is represented by the remaining classes.

A formal walk-through will be developed. For now, the reader should refer to the documentation for the HL7 Reference Information Model for a complete set of attribute descriptions for each class in this RMIM.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: This topic covers the summary and record extract notifications that are used to communicate the care actually given while a subject was under the care of a responsible party.
This is an interaction diagram illustrating all the Interactions and Application Roles relevant to the Care Record Topic.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the report messaging related to a mandatory activation of care, for example primary care physcian (General Practitioner (GP)) report of care to a community agency, eg clinic.

descriptive.name: Care Record Care Provision Announce Mandatory Patient Care Provision
descriptive.p: Activities: Dr. Primary is writing Care Provision summaries for use by the Home Health Care Clinic, describing the care of the patient to date. Dr. Primary records the date of onset of Care Provision by her practice. All information including problem lists, allergy lists, medication lists, progress notes, plans for care, and all other information included in her record is included in the summary.
Postcondition: The Care Provision summary for Mr. Adam Everyman is received by the Home Health Care Clinic who implements care according to the plans of care detailed by Dr. Primary.

Update Requirements Summary: The main communicators in this message are Dr. Primary and the receiving clinician (probably a nurse) in the Home Health Care Clinic (HHCC). The focus of the communication is the provision of data to enable the HHCC to provide ongoing care to Mr Adam Everyman.
Whilst not illustrated here, Dr Primary's clinical system maintains a record of when the Care Provision summary was sent to the HHCC.

story.name: Care Record Care Provision Handover Of Care

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the report messaging related to a temporary handing over of responsibility for care by a care provider who is taking a vacation to another care provider.

descriptive.name: Care Record Temporary Handover Of Care
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Adam Everyman, a 75-year old male patient, is receiving peritoneal dialysis on a trial basis in the assisted living facility where he lives, Home Away from Home, on the orders of Dr. Roy Renal, his nephrologist. After three months, Mr. Everyman appears to be well. He has asked Dr. Renal if he can have a break form the dialysis to see how he goes. Dr. Renal agrees. He prepares a summary detailing the care he has provided to date for Mr. Everyman for Mr. Everyman's primary care physician, Dr. Patricia Primary, advising her of the temporary suspension in Mr. Everyman's dialysis.

Activities: Dr. Renal records the date when he commenced supervision of peritoneal dialysis for Mr. Everyman. Relevant information including problem lists, allergy lists, medication lists, progress notes, plans for care, are included in the summary. [Interaction: ]
Postcondition: The record summarizing the care provided for Mr. Adam Everyman is received by Dr. Primary and uploaded onto her clinical system.

Update Requirements Summary: The actors in this communication are Dr. Renal and Dr. Primary. The focus of the communication is Mr. Everyman's current record of care relating to his peritoneal dialysis provided by Dr. Renal, his status and plan of ongoing care.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the Care Provision Separation Notification and Care Provision Requests for follow up specialty care. The example used here is a Physician Notification of Emergency Encounter Requiring Follow up Specialist Care.

descriptive.name: Care Record Care Provision Physician Notification Of Emergency Encounter
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Adam Everyman is a patient who arrives at Good Health Hospital (GHH) emergency room via ambulance in respiratory distress and with an accelerated heart beat. He is seen by the physician on duty, Dr. Eric Emergency, who decides Mr. Everyman should be treated at this time. Mr. Everyman is checked-in for an ER visit by Mr. Christopher Clerk, the emergency room clerk, who retrieves Mr. Everyman's record from the GHH Patient Registry and creates the emergency check-in. Having administered nebulizer treatment to Mr. Everyman and stabilized him ready for discharge, Dr. Emergency sends an encounter summary to Mr. Everyman's primary care physician, Dr. Patricia Primary. In addition, Mr. Emergency advised Mr. Everyman that he should have a follow-up visit with a pulmonologist specialist and writes a referral request to Dr. Penny Puffer.

Activities: Adam Everyman arrives at GHH ER and is seen by Dr. Eric Emergency who stabilizes him and assesses when he is ready to be checked-out. Dr. Emergency writes a summary of the encounter and sends this to Dr. Patricia Primary, providing details of the assessment, treatment provided and follow up care required [Interaction: ].
Dr. Emergency also sends a referral for Adam Everyman for a follow-up visit to Dr. Penny Puffer [Interaction: ].

Postcondition: The summary of the ER encounter for Adam Everyman is received by Dr. Primary and used to inform ongoing management of Adam Everyman. Dr. Primary notes a referral to Dr. Puffer has also been made and she makes a note to check with Dr. Puffer on the outcome of that follow up visit. The GHH ER clerk completes the checkout information for Mr. Everyman and checks him out of the GHH Emergency Room.

Update Requirements Summary: The primary actors for this communication are Dr. Emergency, Dr. Primary and Dr. Puffer. The foci of the communication are Dr. Emergency's referral request sent to Dr. Puffer and Adam Everyman's ER visit sent to both Drs. Primary and Puffer.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the discharge summary and requests for follow up care by the Attending Physician) and community health services arising from a hospital inpatient encounter.

descriptive.name: Care Record Discharge From Care
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Adam Everyman is an inpatient at Good Health Hospital (GGH). His physician, Dr. Aaron Attend, refers him for thoracic surgery to Dr. Cutter who agrees to perform surgery on Mr. Everyman, adding him to his surgical list at GHH on June 27. Following the thoracic surgery to rule out lung cancer, Dr. Cutter considers that the surgical results indicate Mr. Everyman has lung cancer. He refers Mr. Everyman for a second opinion to Dr. Dunst, a pulmonologist, before proceeding with ongoing care by himself in the Gamma Cancer Clinic. Dr. Cutter also refers Mr. Everyman to the Quit Now for Smoking cessation education program. Dr. Cutter provides an event summary of the surgery to Dr. Attend, who also receives a copy of Mr. Everyman's visit to Quit Now.

Activities: Dr. Attend refers Mr. Everyman to Dr. Cutter with a request for thoracic surgery to rule out lung cancer. He includes a health summary as part of this request [Interaction: ]. Dr Cutter acknowledges this request and confirms he has added Mr Everyman to his surgical list for 27 June [Interaction:].

Following the thoracic surgery on Mr. Everyman Dr. Cutter refers Mr. Everyman for a second opinion to Dr. Dunst. Dr. Cutter compiles a summary of Mr. Everyman's surgery along with the health summary provided by Dr. Attend and sends one referral request to Dr. Dunst and another to the Quit Now for Smoking cessation education program [Interaction: ].

Dr. Cutter also compiles the same summary of Mr. Everyman's surgery along with the proposed care plan and sends these to both the Hospital Surgical Review Board and Dr. Attend. This notification includes details of the procedures performed, the surgical findings and an adverse event that occurred during the procedure [Interaction: ].
Following Mr. Everyman's visits to Quit Now, a report on these visits is sent by Quit Now to Dr. Primary for her records [Interaction: ].

Postcondition: Having referred Mr. Everyman to Dr. Cutter, Dr. Attend receives a discharge summary report on the outcome of the surgical referral, including post surgical follow up treatment and care and ongoing progress reports from the Quit Now service.

Update Requirements Summary: The actors for this communication are Drs. Attend, Cutter, Dunst and the Quit Now clinic. The foci of the communication are Dr. Attend's health summary and referral request to Dr. Cutter, Dr. Cutter's referral request and inpatient surgical summary sent to Dr. Dunst and the Quit Now clinic, Dr. Cutter's inpatient surgical summary and proposed plan of care sent to Dr. Attend, and the Quit Now clinic visit summary sent to Dr. Attend.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request

story.name: Care Record Ongoing Specialist Care Provision

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the request and report messaging related to Care Provision (Event Summary). The example used is a General Practitioner (GP) request of specialty care with ongoing care report.

descriptive.name: Care Record Gp Request Of Specialty Advice With Ongoing Report
descriptive.familiarName: Care Record Ongoing Specialist Care Provision
descriptive.p: Precondition: Dr. Patricia Primary, Primary Care Physician at Good Health Hospital (GHH) Outpatient Clinic, is seeing a 75-year old male patient Mr. Adam Everyman, complaining of pain in his hip joint. She refers Mr. Everyman to Dr. Joint, a rheumatologist at GHH Patient Ward, with a request for him to see and give advice regarding Mr. Everyman's' complaint. Dr. Joint is under no contract or legal obligation to see the patient. Dr. Joint agrees to see Mr. Everyman. Mr. Everyman has an initial consultation with Dr. Joint and subsequent three monthly followup meetings. Following each visit Dr. Joint sends Dr. Primary a progress report on Mr. Everyman.

Activities: Dr. Primary refers Mr. Everyman to Dr. Joint with a copy of Mr. Everyman's' clinical summary and relevant clinical history to date [Interaction: ]. Dr. Joint agrees to see Mr. Everyman and notifies Dr. Primary to that effect [Interaction: ].

Once Dr. Joint has seen Mr. Everyman he sends Dr. Primary a report containing a summary of his exam and an outline of his intended ongoing care management [Interaction: ]. Every subsequent three months Dr. Joint provides progress reports on Mr. Everyman to Dr. Primary [Interaction: ].

Postcondition: Dr. Primary receives an initial and three monthly reports from Dr. Joint on Mr. Everyman's progress and takes the information contained therein into account in her ongoing treatment of Mr. Everyman's other health problems.

Update Requirements Summary: The actors for this communication are Dr. Primary and Dr. Joint. The foci of this communication are Dr. Primary's referral request to Dr. Joint, Dr. Joint's initial consultation summary plus Dr. Joint's subsequent examination summaries and ongoing plans of care sent to Dr. Primary.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the report messaging related to the separation Care Provision.

descriptive.name: Care Record Care Provision Notify Care Provision Summary
descriptive.p: Precondition: Dr. Primary, Primary Care Physician in Good Health Hospital (GHH) Outpatient Clinic, has been seeing a 75-year old male patient Mr. Everyman, with multiple health problems. Dr. Primary is closing her practice and is writing Care Provision summaries for use by the patient and providers whom the patient elects to see.

Activities: Dr. Primary records the date of onset of Care Provision by her practice and the date care ended in her practice. All information including problem lists, allergy lists, medication lists, progress notes, plans for care, and all other information included in her record is included in the summary [Interaction: ].

Postcondition: Mr. Everyman's health record is updated as a result of the Care Provision summaries provided by Dr. Primary so that they are available for him and other care providers he elects to share these with.
Update Requirements Summary: The actor for this communication is Dr. Primary. The focus of this communication is Mr. Everyman's record of care provided by Dr. Primary.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see and their relationships in the Version 3 Guide.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An application that is capable of notifying another system about a care record event.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An application that is capable of notifying another system about a care record triggered by a user or other external action.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An application that is capable of receiving a notification from another system about a care record event.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: An application that is capable of receiving a notification from another system about a care record triggered by a user or other external action.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

trigger.name: Care Record Event Replace Obsolete Notification

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates that details about the care provision for a subject are obsolete and have been replaced.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates that the responsibility of care provision has been activated (started) and the receiving application is being informed without being asked to act on it.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates additional details about the care provision for a subject.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates corrections to details about the care provision for a subject.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates that the responsibility of care provision has been suspended and the receiving application is being informed without being asked to act on it.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates that the responsibility of care provision has been resumed and the receiving application is being informed without being asked to act on it.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates that the responsibility of care provision has been aborted and the receiving application is being informed without being asked to act on it.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates that the completion of a care provision has occurred and that the receiving application is being informed without being asked to act on it. A completed care provision indicates that the performer is no long responsible for the subject patients' provision of care.

trigger.name: Care Record Event Nullify
trigger.descriptive: Indicates that the related care provision previously recorded was done so incorrectly or inappropriately and has been withdrawn from existence.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Indicates to the receiver details about care provision collected up to and including that point in time.

descriptive.name: Reference
descriptive.p: For details on the interpretation of this section, see in the Version 3 Guide.

rmim.name: Care Record Event
rmim.descriptive:
Care Record RMIM Overview
The Care Record RMIM captures the data and associations that are needed when the responsibility of Care Provision has been assumed and a record summary of the acts relevant to the care provision including any requested, proposed or activated care plans. This model, and its accompanying diagram, is very similar to the Care Provision DMIM but uses "local CMETs" to abstract the complexity of the care structures associated with the Care Provision Request Act. The reader should refer to the DMIM discussion before reviewing the RMIM followed by the discussion for each care structure. The discussion of this model will focus on features that do not exist in the DMIM, and were not directly addressed in the review of that model. CareProvisionEvent Focal Class
As noted in the discussion of the DMIM a Care Provision Event records and summarizes the acts relevant whilst the performer is responsible for the care provision of the target of care. Associations
The following associations are defined for a Care Record. Each association captures the relationship between the Care Provision Event and an entity or act that plays a significant part of the Care Record. Participations
recordTarget: the record target is the entity for which the Care Record is being recorded. There can only be one record target for a Care Record. The target entity information is captured within the R_Patient CMET or R_CaredEntity local CMET. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
subject: the subject or subjects are the target(s) of the care provision being record when the subject is not the record target. The subject information is captured within the R_Patient CMET or R_CaredEntity local CMET. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
author: the party that produces the record of a Care Provision Event. This may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member or a non-healthcare organization, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
dataEnterer: the transcriptionist who enters the information of the Care Record. The data enterer information is captured within the R_AssignedPerson CMET.
verifier: the supervisor who verifies the Care Record. There is support for more than one level of verification. The verifying party information is captured within the R_AssignedPerson CMET.
performer: the parties who take part in actually carrying out the Care Provision Event being record. There may be multiple performers because several parties may collaborate in performance of Care Provision. These parties may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member or a non-healthcare organization, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
primaryInformationRecipient: the party who is intended to receive the Care Record notification. The recipient is usually the author of the associated care transfer request or the primary care provider. These may be represented by an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty), a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member or court, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description. Act Relationships
inFullfilmentOf: this relationship links the Care Provision Event to the promise and/or request Act that it fulfills. Only the id attribute is provided to link the Act for which the Care Provision Event fulfills.
component: links the Care Provision Event to the care plan which is carried out as part of the Care Provision. Refer to A_CarePlan in the Care Structures topic for further description this local CMET.
pertinentInformation1: links the Care Provision Event to the care plan which is informative in the context of the care provision but not directly relevant to this Care Record. Refer to A_CarePlan in the Care Structures topic for further description this local CMET.
pertinentInformation3: links the Care Provision Event to a set of pertinent clinical statements provided as part of the information supplied in the Care Record. Refer to A_CareStatement in the Care Structures topic for further description this local CMET.
reason: a relationship to a concern recorded as the primary reason for the Care Provision. A problem, not specifically a diagnosis, which is the primary reason for the Care Provision can also be presented using this relationship. Refer to A_ConcernTracking in the Care Structures topic for further description this local CMET.
pertinentInformation2: a Care Record has a set of lists containing various Clinical Statements as relevant information, which is ongoing and not necessarily captured as part of the Care Provision Event. It may include a problem list, current medication list or a list of risk factors. Refer to A_StatementCollector in the Care Structures topic for further description this local CMET.
Reference: the Care Event or Care Events (encounter-based, episode-based, or general care-based collections) that the Care Record relates to, represented by the A_CareEvent CMET
ReplacementOf: a link to a replaced Care Record. The Care Provision Event being the target of this act relationship has a status of obsolete and can either contain just the instance identifier of the replaced Care Record or the entire Care Record information.

story.name: Query Care Record Aged Care Assessment
story.descriptive: This storyboard demonstrates querying a state or national database of eligibility for aged care assessment records to establish currency (expiry date), scope (respite, permanent, high care/low care, community, residential etc) of an existing eligibility record; which aged care assessment providers undertook the eligibility assessment; and whether any expired eligibility assessment record for the same individual exists.

descriptive.name: Query Care Record Aged Care Assessment
descriptive.p: Nancy Nightingale is evaluating whether she can provide a package of community based services to potential client Mrs. Eve Everywoman. However, it is not clear from the application form (completed on her behalf by her husband, Boris Betterhalf) whether Mrs. Everywoman has been assessed as eligible for this subsidized service. As she is authorized to access the national aged care eligibility assessment forms registry and has Mr. Betterhalf's consent, Nancy Nightingale sends a request to the national registry to determine whether a current or previous aged care eligibility assessment form exists for Mrs. Everywoman.

Nancy Nightingale logs onto the national aged care eligibility assessment registry. She enters Mrs. Everywoman's details to query whether a current or previous eligibility assessment exists for Mrs. Everywoman. She receives a response confirming that an eligibility assessment was completed two years previously, is now expired, and was undertaken by an assessment team in Melbourne, where Mrs. Everywoman used to live.

Nancy Nightingale notifies Mrs. Everywoman that she requires a current eligibility assessment before she can process her application for community based services. She advises Mrs. Everywoman she will make arrangements for her to be seen by an eligibility assessment team who will be able to re-assess her care needs and eligibility for government subsidized services.

The communicators of this query message, Nancy Nightingale and the national registry system, ensure ready access by clinicians to copies of current or preexisting aged care eligibility assessment records, avoiding delays in accessing services due to expired or non existent assessment records.

story.name: Query Care Record Patient Populates Personal Health Record
story.descriptive: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate requests for components of care records.

descriptive.name: Query Care Record Patient Populates Personal Ehr
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Adam Everyman wishes to populate a personal health record with information on his condition from Dr. Patricia Primary held in her clinical system.

Activities: Mr. Adam Everyman requests specific information relating to his cardiac condition from Dr. Patricia Primary [Interaction: ]. Dr. Primary responds by sending the answers to the specific information requested to Mr. Everyman who is able to incorporate the information into his own personal health record [Interaction: ]. Mr Everyman uploads the information on his cardiac condition into his personal health record [Interaction: ].

Alternate flow: Mr Everyman requests copies of particular test results and treatments relating to his cardiac condition from Dr Primary [Interaction: ]. Dr Primary responds by sending the requested documents to Mr Everyman .[Interaction: ]
Postcondition: Mr. Everyman now has all the documents and information he requires on his cardiac condition from Dr. Primary.
Updates Requirement Summary: The communicators of this storyboard, Mr. Everyman and Dr Primary, are focused on the sourcing and exchange of extracts of Mr. Everyman's patient record.
Note: This storyboard is supported under the Care Record Query Topic and the Care Record Document Topic. Care Record Summary document is the document type that would be returned by Physician A.
