rmim.name: Query Care Record Event Find Candidate

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Find Care Record Candidate Query request RMIM provides the list of query parameters needed to retrieve a list of summarized Care Records based on the specified criteria. These query parameters are as follows:

list.item: PatientId: The unique identifier (II) of the patient whose records are being retrieved. The parameter is mandatory and should contain exactly one patient identifer, which must not be null.

PatientName: The label (PN) by which the patient whose records are being retrieved is known and communicated with. The patient name is used for verification of the patient identifier for the query request. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one patient name.

PatientAdministrativeGender: Indicates the gender (CE) of the patient whose records are being retrieved. Used to assist in identification of the patient accurately, in the context of other parameters. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one gender code value.

PatientBirthTime: The calendar date (TS) on which a patient whose records are being retrieved was born. Used to assist in identification of the patient accurately, in the context of other parameters. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one date value.

CareRecordTimePeriod: The date range (IVL<TS>) of Care Record contributions to be included in the candidate list. A query can request new contribution that have been processed for this patient since the last query request. For example, a system can query about a patient each month and only get the new contributions to the patient's health record. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one date range.

CareProvisionCode: The code (CD) representing the type of the Care Records to be retrieved. A query can request a list of Care Records of a specific type, such as a hospital discharge summary, or a more general grouping of Care Record types, such as ambulatory patient visits. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one type of Care Record code value.

CareProvisionReason: The code (CD) representing the condition that is the "reason" for the Care Provision reported in the Care Record. A query can request a list of Care Records that are related to managing a current or previous condition, such as Pregnancy. The parameter is required to be supported allows multiple care provision reason code values.

MaximumCandidates: The maximum number (INT) of candidate Care Records to be returned that match the query criteria. For example 15= fifteen most recent Care Records that match the query criteria, unspecified= all Care Records that match the query criteria. The default is for all Care Records to be returned. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one integer value.

hmdref.refName: Query Care Record Event Find Candidate

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Care Record Query request RMIM provides the list of query parameters needed to retreive a specific Care Record determined by its unique identifier. These query parameters are as follows:

list.item: CareRecordId: The unique identifier (II) of the Care Record to be retrieved. The parameter is mandatory and should contain exactly one Care Record identifier which must not be null.

PatientId: The unique identifier (II) of the patient whose record is being retrieved. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one patient identifier. This parameter can be provided to ensure that Care Record being requested is for the correct patient or when Care Record identfiers are only unique for a particular patient.

VersionTimestamp: The date/time (TS) at which point the state of the Care Record retrieved should be reflected, that is, retreive the Care Record snapshot at that point in time. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one timestamp.

IncludeCarePlanAttachment: An indicator (BL) that, if set to true, would include any care plan attachments that are available. If set to false, care plan attachments would not be sent or returned in the query response. The default is 'false'. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one boolean indicator.

MaximumHistoryStatements: The number (INT) of repetitions of each type of historical clinical statement (e.g. A1Cs, weight, dispensed medications, etc.) to be returned. For example 1= most recent, 2= last two clinical statements, unspecified= all available clinical statements. The default is for all records to be returned. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one integer value.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The Care Record Profile Query request RMIM provides the list of query parameters needed to retreive a care profile derived from patient health record matching the criteria parameters. These query parameters are as follows:

list.item: PatientId: The unique identifer (II) of the patient whose records are being retreived. The parameter is mandatory and should contain exactly one patient identifer, which must not be null.

PatientName: The label (PN) by which the patient whose records are being retreived is known and communicated with. The patient name is used for verification of the patient identifier for the query request. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one patient name.

PatientAdministrativeGender: Inidcates the gender (CE) of the patient whose records are being retreived. Used to assist in identification of the patient accurately, in the context of other parameters. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one gender code value.

PatientBirthTime: The calender date (TS) on which a patient whose records are being retreived was born. Used to assist in identification of the patient accurately, in the context of other parameters. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one date value.

ClinicalStatementTimePeriod: The date range (IVL<TS>) of the Clinical Statements to be included in the retrieved Care Record profile. For example when the lab test was resulted, when the drug was dispensed, when the procedure occurred, etc. This parameter allows for the filtering of clinical statments in a query response. Only clinical statement, with date attributes that fall within this date range will be included in the query response. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one date range.

CareRecordTimePeriod: The date range (IVL<TS>) of Care Record contributions to be included in the candidate list. A query can request new contribution that have been processed for this patient since the last query request. For example, a system can query about a patient each month and only get the new contributions to the patient's health record. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one date range.

CareProvisionCode: The code (CD) representing the type of the Care Records to be retreived. A query can request a list of Care Records of a specific type, such as a hospital discharge summary, or a more general grouping of Care Record types, such as ambulatory patient visits. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one type of Care Record code value.

CareProvisionReason: The code (CD) representing the condition that is the "reason" for the Care Provision reported in the Care Record. A query can request a list of Care Records that are related to managing a current or previous condition, such as Pregnancy. The parameter is required to be supported The parameter is required to be supported and allows multiple care provision reason code values.

MaximumHistoryStatements: The number (INT) of repetitions of each type of historical clinical statement (e.g. A1Cs, weight, dispensed medications, etc.) to be returned. For example 1= most recent, 2= last two clincial statements, unspecified= all available clinical statments. The default is for all records to be returned. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one integer value.

IncludeCarePlanAttachment: An indicator (BL) that, if set to true, would include any care plan attachments that are available. If set to false, care plan attachments would not be sent or returned in the query response. The default is 'false'. The parameter is required to be supported but has a maximum of just one boolean indicator.

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: This topic covers the business cycle of requests and promises that are included in negotiations regarding the transfer of responsibility for care.

Traditionally, this set of communications has been called a "referral." However, referrals tend to have specific meanings within various cultures, and an attempt has been made to create an overall definition of referral that is quite general. In order to avoid confusion among cultures, the individual messages do not use the term "referral". Rather they identify specific use cases and triggers related to communications that use the HL7 RIM "Act" class of "CareProvision (PCPR)" as the "entry point" of the refined message information model (RMIM) for Care Transfer message development.

Care Transfer is the communication between an Author and a Health Care Provider with the intent of negotiating an assumption of responsibility for the care by the receiver of the request. An assumption of responsibility is constrained to a statement of the scope of the responsibility including the type of care, the specific conditions named, and the specific care plans named, where:
'Communication' may be by way of

list.item: messaging with or without an attached clinical document, e.g care transfer summary.

descriptive.p: 'Communication' may be triggered by

list.item: request for shared care (partial transfer of care responsibility)
request for complete transfer of care responsibility

descriptive.p: 'Author' of care transfer communications can be

list.item: clinicians
healthcare agencies (including district nursing, community health, social welfare)
patient (self referral)
patient family/significant others
court or other non health care organization
devices authorized by organizations

descriptive.p: 'Health care providers' can be

list.item: clinicians
healthcare agencies (including district nursing, community health, social welfare)

descriptive.p: This is an interaction diagram illustrating all the Interactions and Application Roles relevant to the Care Transfer Topic.

story.name: Care Transfer Changes In Ongoing Services
story.familiarName: Request for Changes in Ongoing Service

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates the communication flow between a client/resident or their advocate requesting a change to an existing service.

descriptive.name: Care Record Changes To Ongoing Services
descriptive.familiarName: Request for Changes in Ongoing Services

story.descriptive:
Precondition: Mr. Adam Everyman, who lives at home receives the equivalent of one meal a day from the meals on wheels service operated by the Green Acres Retirement Home (GARH) group. His daughter, who pays the client contribution towards the cost of this service, notes he is continuing to lose weight and persuades Mr. Everyman to change his current order to two meals a day.
Activities: On behalf of her father, Nancy Nuclear sends a request to GARH's hospitality service with a request for changes to her father's existing meals service [Interaction: ]. Before the catering services client manager can arrange the additional meal for Mr. Everyman, Ms. Nuclear is required to authorize the additional client contribution. The Dietician, Connie Chow sends an authorization request to Ms. Nuclear. Ms. Nuclear is happy to pay the extra contribution for the additional daily meal and advises Connie Chow to proceed. Upon receipt of the authorization acceptance, the hospitality service confirms the new arrangements will be put into place e.g. arrange the additional meal [Interaction are in place for Mr. Everyman's meals by sending a new care plan to Ms. Nuclear [Interaction: ].
Postcondition: Arrangements are in place for Mr. Everyman to receive two meals per day, with the revised invoice going to his daughter. Having made the necessary arrangements with the meals on wheels delivery service, Connie Chow's ordering systems automatically sends a message to the GARH client account system advising of the additional charges to be invoiced to Ms. Nuclear as the designated payor for Mr. Everyman.
Update Requirements Summary: The communicators of this storyboard, Ms. Nuclear, on behalf of her father, and the dietician, Connie Chow, are focused on ensuring that requested changes to ongoing services (in this case catering) are actioned in a timely manner, with documentation of appropriate authorizations.

story.name: Care Transfer Completed Specialty Care

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard describes a typical consultation interaction between a Primary Care Physcian and a Specialist.

story.descriptive:
Precondition: Dr. Patricia Primary is a primary care physician who has been seeing a patient regularly for some time and utilizing her standard care plans for the condition. The patient's condition is worsening, and Dr. Primary wishes to obtain the opinion of a gastroenterologist specialist, Dr. Tony Tum.
Activities: Dr. Primary prepares a summary from the existing electronic medical records highlighting the reason for the consultation, including summaries of the other medical conditions for which the patient receives care, and including the medication list, allergy list, and lists of prior surgeries and hospitalizations. This summary is sent to Dr. Tum along with a request to see the patient [Interaction: ]. Dr. Tum decides to see the patient and sends the appropriate response back to Dr. Primary [Interaction: ]. Dr. Tum then sees the patient, prepares a summary of his evaluation and opinions on change of treatment [Interaction: ]. Dr. Tum sends the summary to Dr. Primary, who alters the care plans with the recommended changes.
Alternative flows:
Dr. Tum may decline the request to see the patient [Interaction: ] >>Post-Condition: Dr. Primary tries another gastroenterologist specialist.
Dr. Tum may send recommendations without seeing the patient (paper consultation).
Dr. Tum may request more information before seeing the patient (not illustrated).
Dr. Primary may send more information without a request for more information [Interaction: ].
Postcondition: Dr. Primary returns to seeing the patient on a regular basis, now utilizing the altered care plans for the patient.
Updates Requirements Summary: The communicators of these messages, Dr. Primary and Dr. Tum are focused on the referral request from Dr. Primary and the outcome of that referral back to Dr. Primary. This includes the capacity for Dr. Primary to provide updated information to Dr. Tum as it comes to hand during the consultation.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request
Care Transfer Request Revise Fulfillment Request

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates the communication flow associated with requests by a Primary Care Physician (GP) to other clinical or allied health care providers to contribute to the delivery of a multidisciplinary care plan, such as a Chronic Disease Management care plan (CDM). CDMs are designed to improve the medical management of care for a person with chronic or complex care needs. (In Australia the GP is encouraged to collaborate with other providers if the patient has complex care needs which would benefit form multidisciplinary care team input. Similar initiatives exist in many countries.)

descriptive.name: Care Transfer Multidisciplinary Care Provision
descriptive.p: Precondition: Dr Patricia Primary is preparing a multidisciplinary care plan for Mr Adam Everyman to improve his health outcomes and quality of life goals associated with his diabetes and hypertension. She recommends to Mr Everyman involving a physiotherapist, a nutritionist and his daughter, Nancy Nuclear. Dr Primary obtains Mr Everyman's authorization to share his medical history and goals with the other providers and his daughter.
Dr Primary sends an individual request to Physiotherapist Seth Stretcher, Nutritionist Connie Chow and to Mr Everyman's daughter, Nancy Nuclear [Interaction: ].
Each in turn send a response to confirm they will make arrangements to meet with Mr Everyman to develop a plan to meet the particular goals specified by Dr Primary [Interaction: ].

In turn Seth Stretcher and Connie Chow meet with Mr Everyman and his daughter to review his goals in relation to his diabetes and hypertension. Each prepares a care plan for Mr Everyman which they summarise and forward to Dr Primary [Interaction: ]. Dr Primary distills these contributions into an overall Chronic Disease Management care plan and provides copies to each of the members of the multidisciplinary care planning team including Mr Everyman's daughter, who under the plan has been identified as responsible for assisting Mr Everyman with his meals [Interaction: ] each acknowledge their undertaking to action the revised, composite care plan [Interaction: ].

Each provider continues to see or communicate with Mr Everyman to review his response to the respective components to the plan of care. They provide a summary report on progress to Dr Primary [Interaction: ].

Three weeks later, Dr Primary meets with Mr Everyman and his daughter to review progress in the management of his diabetes and hypertension. While he has achieved some of his goals, Mr Everyman is disappointed in the progress with those relating to stabilizing his blood sugar levels. Dr Primary amends the goals for Mr Everyman and sends these to Connie Chow and Nancy Nuclear [Interaction: ].
Connie Chow and Nancy Nuclear review their care plans for Mr Everyman in light of the new goals from Dr Primary and provide ongoing progress reports on the new care plans [Interaction: ].
Postcondition: Mr Everyman receives team based care, coordinated and reviewed by his Primary Care Physician, Dr Primary.

Updates Requirement Summary: The participants of this storyboard are Dr Primary, Physiotherapist Seth Stretcher, Nutritionist Connie Chow and the patient's daughter, Nancy Nuclear. They are focused on responding to a request by Dr Primary to collaborate on the development of an integrated care plan for Mr Everyman to improve his health outcomes and quality of life goals associated with his diabetes and hypertension.

story.name: Care Transfer Request Aged Care Service
story.descriptive: This storyboard demonstrates the flow of communication between a party seeking a community or residential aged care service place and the admissions system of an ageing services provider organization. Note the outcome of this storyboard relates to the success or otherwise of a request to access services ("do you have a vacancy?") - it says nothing about whether an admission or acceptance of place/bed occurs. The latter is contingent upon completion of contractual documentation etc.

descriptive.name: Care Transfer Request Aged Care Service
descriptive.p: Precondition:Peter Process is the social worker at Good Health Hospital (GHH) responsible for coordinating in patient discharges for older patients. His role is to maximize the successful return of frail elderly inpatients to the community, including to residential aged care services. He works closely with the ageing services (home care and residential) in the surrounding area. He is looking for a nursing home placement for a Mr. Everyman who requires some intensive rehabilitation following a fall before he can safely return to living with his daughter who works full time. He recommends Green Acres Retirement Home (GARH) as a suitable provider organization to Mr. Everyman and his daughter, Nancy Nuclear, who authorizes him to approach GARH on his behalf, along with three other nursing homes within 5 miles radius of Ms Nuclear's home.

Peter Process forwards a request for a temporary nursing home placement for Mr. Everyman to Alice Admitter commencing the process of referral for ageing services. [Interaction: ]. As she is processing the referral Alice Admitter notes Peter Process has not included all of Mr. Everyman's insurance details. She sends the request back to Peter Process, indicating the request cannot be processed in its current form [Interaction: ].

Alice Admitter accepts the referral for processing by identifying the request as 'Accepted' (or active) in the GARH admissions database. This triggers an automatic progress report on the referral to Peter Process at GHH [Interaction: ]. She then forwards the request to Nancy Nightingale to review [Interaction: ].

Nancy Nightingale sends a request for further clinical information on Mr. Everyman's cognitive functional capacity to Peter Process at GHH who on this occasion had not attached the full cognitive assessment findings. [Interaction: Care Provision Event, Query.] As he had already obtained Mr. Everyman's consent to share his assessment findings with other service providers, Peter Process attaches the summary of Mr. Everyman's cognitive and behavioral assessment, including the scores from the assessments undertaken in the hospital of his cognitive, behavioral and mood status. He sends this to Nancy Nightingale. [Interaction: Care Provision Event Query, Response]. (Note these query interactions are out of scope of current storyboard).

Following her review of Mr. Everyman's rehabilitation and care needs, Nancy Nightingale is happy to offer the one remaining vacant bed at GARH to Mr. Everyman. She advises Alice Admitter of this decision [Interaction: ]. Alice Admitter promptly notifies Peter Process of the vacancy [Interaction: ].

This action simultaneously updates GARH's 'Active Referrals' file, maintained by Alice Admitter, completing the audit trail for this request for services. Mr. Everyman's name is not removed from the 'Active Referral's file until notification is received that all contractual documentation is in place and that he has actually been admitted to GARH.

list.item: Peter Process receives a call from Mr. Everyman's daughter to advise she is taking parental leave for two months so her father can be discharged directly home to live with her. Following the leave (when she returns to work) she will reassess whether her father still needs to receive formal ageing services. Peter Process immediately notifies Alice Admitter and Nancy Nightingale that the request for services for Mr. Everyman is withdrawn [Interaction: ]. >>Postcondition: Peter Process discharges Mr. Everyman home.

Having read the detailed cognitive and behavioral assessment report for Mr. Everyman, Nancy Nightingale determines the respite bed she currently has available (for short term admission only) will not be adequate to meet the rehabilitation goals set for Mr. Everyman. She notifies Alice Admitter who in turn notifies Peter Process, Mr. Everyman and his daughter of the outcome of the decision. [Interaction: ]. >>Postcondition: Peter Process contacts the other nursing home facilities in the area in the hope of finding a suitable placement for Mr. Everyman.

Alice Admitter advises Ms Nuclear that GARH will be able to offer the next permanent nursing home bed to her father when it becomes available but she is unable to say precisely when that will be. Ms Nuclear is delighted and happy to wait on a place as GARH is her father's preferred choice of nursing home. Alice Admitter adds Mr. Everyman's name to the GARH Waiting List for permanent placement. She notifies Peter Process of this outcome as Mr. Everyman has yet to be discharged from hospital [Interaction: ]. >>Postcondition: Peter Process delays Mr. Everyman's discharge in the hope a bed becomes available for him at GARH.

descriptive.p: Update Requirements Summary: The communicators of these messages, Peter Process (on behalf of Mr Brown), Alice Admitter and Nancy Nightingale are focused on the referral request designed to locate an aged care placement as smoothly and quickly as possible, whilst ensuring the suitability of that placement.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request
Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request
Care Transfer Request Abort Fulfillment Notification

story.name: Care Transfer Request Aged Care Service (lite)

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the communication flow between a person requesting access to aged care services and a residential or community aged care service provider organisation.

descriptive.name: Care Transfer Request Aged Care Service (lite)
descriptive.p: Precondition: Peter Process, Discharge Planner at Good Health Hospital is looking for a nursing home placement for Mr. Adam Everyman, 88 yrs in-patient close to where his son lives. He sends requests to transfer Mr. Everyman to five nursing homes, including Green Acres Retirement Home (GARH), where the Admissions Officer is Alice Admitter.

Acting on Mr. Everyman's authorization, Peter Process forwards a request for services, including a copy of Mr. Everyman's eligibility assessment, to five nursing homes in closest proximity to where his son lives. [Interaction: ]. He receives automatic acknowledgement from four of these nursing homes that his request has been received. Three weeks later, Peter Process receives advice from Alice Admitter, that Mr. Everyman has been offered a nursing home place at GARH and that he is to be admitted the next day. [Interaction: ].
Having secured a place for Mr. Everyman at GARH, Peter Process, immediately notifies the three other nursing homes of his withdrawal of his Request for Service for Mr. Everyman. [Interaction: ].
Postcondition: Peter Process makes arrangements for Mr. Everyman's discharge and transfer to GARH, having withdrawn his requests from the other nursing homes.

Updates Requirement Summary: Having successfully found a place for Mr. Everyman, Peter Process is able to focus on placement of other elderly inpatients. His information system gives him some information (via an audit trail) of how long respective nursing homes are taking to respond to requests for service. He uses this information to target his next requests.

Care Transfer Request Abort Fulfillment Notification

story.name: Care Transfer Request Medication Chart Review

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard demonstrates a request by a nurse of a Primary Care Physician (GP) to review a resident's medication chart.

descriptive.name: Care Transfer Request Medication Chart Review

story.descriptive:
Precondition: Nancy Nightingale, RN at Green Acres Retirement Home, is concerned that Mr. Everyman's pain management is no longer effective. She feels a review of all his medications might be in order. She discusses her concerns with the Palliative Care Clinical Consultant who agrees a review of all Mr. Everyman's current medication is a good idea.
Activities: Nancy Nightingale sends a request to Dr. Patricia Primary outlining the need for a review of Mr. Everyman's medication chart. She provides a copy of the 24 hour pain chart findings which demonstrates Mr. Everyman is experiencing too frequent breakthrough of pain [Interaction: ].
Dr. Primary notifies Nancy Nightingale she will visit Mr. Everyman later that day [Interaction: ]. Dr. Primary visits Mr. Everyman later that day and with Nancy Nightingale reviews all Mr. Everyman's medications. She provides a revised Medication Chart for Mr. Everyman [Interaction: Medication Administration Order Activate, Fulfillment Request]. As Nancy Nightingale uploads the new medication chart into the electronic drug chart system an automatic message is sent to the off-site Pharmacist's System to notify the changed orders for Mr. Everyman [Interaction: Combined Order Activate, Fulfillment Request]. (N.B Medication order messages are out of scope of this storyboard.)
Alternative view: Dr. Primary receives the request from Nancy Nightingale but feels a review is not required at this time [Interaction: ].
Postcondition: Mr. Everyman commences on a new medication regime that same evening. Nancy Nightingale continues the pain management chart and over the next 12 hours Mr. Everyman reports no pain breakthrough with no loss of concentration.
Update Requirements Summary: The communicators of this message, RN, Nancy Nightingale and Dr. Primary, are focused on requesting and completing a review of Mr. Everyman's medication chart. The outcome of the review is communicated to the off-site pharmacy so that the new supplies can be provided directly to the nursing home in a timely manner.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: This storyboard illustrates the communication flow associated with provision of pastoral care services involving paid and unpaid service providers.

descriptive.name: Care Transfer Request Pastoral Care
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mrs. Eve Everywoman is a resident in the Green Acres Retirement Home (GARH) who is receiving palliative care. She has insight into her deteriorating condition which is causing her high stress and anxiety. Her husband, Neville Nuclear, feels she has unresolved issues she needs to deal with in relation to her eldest daughter, with whom she has been estranged for the past five years. Mr. Nuclear feels this anxiety is counteracting the pain medication she is taking. He is aware that GARH has an excellent pastoral care service, which draws upon trained volunteers from local organizations, including the local Catholic Church. He discusses with his wife the idea of contacting someone for her to talk with "in private" about their daughter.

Larry Listener, Director of Pastoral Care, receives a call from Mrs. Everywoman's husband requesting pastoral care services for his wife. As GARH is part of the region managed by Pastoral Care Coordinator Helen Helper, Larry Listener sends a note to ask Helen to arrange services for Mrs. Everywoman [Interaction: ]. Helen Helper confirms with Larry Listener that she has received the request and that she has made an appointment to visit Mrs. Everywoman the following day [Interaction: ].

Following her visit and assessment of Mrs. Everywoman, Helen Helper prepares a care plan for Mrs. Everywoman based on their discussions. She checks her list of pastoral care volunteers to see who has the capacity to take on Mrs. Everywoman's care. As she only meets with her volunteers monthly Helen Helper sends a request to Valerie Volunteer, who is both a Catholic and whose case-load has recently been reduced. She asks Valerie if she is available to take on a new client, providing details of Mrs. Everywoman's location and the contact details of the Residential Care Coordinator [Interaction: ].
Valerie Volunteer accesses the request via her mobile phone. She notifies Helen Helper that she is able to take on Mrs. Everywoman, subject to Mrs. Everywoman's acceptance [Interaction: ].

Helen Helper advises Larry Listener that Valerie Volunteer has been assigned to Mrs. Everywoman and that a care plan is in place that has been agreed to with Mrs. Everywoman. A copy of this message is sent to Nancy Nightingale, the Residential Care Coordinator, so that she can upload Valerie Volunteer's contact details and a copy of the pastoral care plan into the nursing documentation system [Interaction: ].

Valerie Volunteer commences visits with Mrs. Everywoman. With reference to the pastoral care plan, she documents each visit incorporating information on the duration of her visit (detailed notes of their discussions are not recorded). The care documentation system automatically sends a summary of Valerie Volunteer's initial visit to Helen Helper. [Interaction: ].This allows Helen Helper to monitor the quality and level of activity of her team of pastoral care volunteers, in addition to providing an audit trail of this and subsequent pastoral care activities [Interaction: ].

After six visits Mrs. Everywoman is reconciled with her daughter. Mrs. Everywoman requests a temporary suspension of visits while she enjoys time with her daughter. Valerie Volunteer documents this outcome in Mrs. Everywoman's records and sends a summary of the last visit to Helen Helper who records a requested suspension in pastoral care services. [Interaction: ]. In turn she sends a copy of this message to the Director of Pastoral Care, Larry Listener [Interaction: ].

Postcondition: Documentation of the impact of the pastoral care services provided to Mrs. Everywoman by Valerie Volunteer appears in the nursing documentation. In addition, Helen Helper has been able to maintain an arms length observation of the frequency and duration of Valerie Volunteer's visits. Should Mrs. Everywoman request further pastoral care services, the relevant details of this recent service will be available for the requesting staff member.

Updates Requirement Summary: The communicators of this interaction, the Director of Pastoral Care, a Regional Pastoral Care Coordinator and the carer providing the actual Pastoral Care, are focused on responding to requests for the provision of pastoral care and on monitoring who and when pastoral care services are being provided.

intref.refName: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request

story.name: Care Transfer Surgical Referral

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate a referral for surgery by a General Practitioner to a surgeon and the second opinions requested by that surgeon associated with a hospital inpatient encounter.

story.descriptive:
Precondition: Mr. Adam Everyman is an inpatient at Good Health Hospital (GHH). His physician, Dr. Aaron Attend, refers him for thoracic surgery to Dr. Cutter who agrees to perform surgery on Mr. Everyman, adding him to his surgical list at GHH on June 27. Following the thoracic surgery to rule out lung cancer, Dr. Cutter considers that the surgical results indicate Mr. Everyman has lung cancer. He refers Mr. Everyman for a second opinion to Dr. Dunst, a pulmonologist, before proceeding with ongoing care by himself in the Gamma Cancer Clinic. Dr. Cutter also refers Mr. Everyman to the Quit Now for Smoking cessation education program.
Activities: Dr. Attend refers Mr. Everyman to Dr. Cutter with a request for thoracic surgery to rule out lung cancer. He includes a health summary as part of this request [Interaction: ]. Dr Cutter acknowledges this request and confirms he has added Mr Everyman to his surgical list for 27 June [Interaction ].
Following the thoracic on Mr. Everyman Dr. Cutter refers Mr. Everyman for a second opinion to Dr. Dunst. Dr. Cutter compiles a summary of Mr. Everyman's surgery along with the health summary provided by Dr. Attend and sends one referral request to Dr. Dunst and another to the Quit Now for Smoking cessation education program [Interaction: ], both acknowledge the request to Dr Cutter [Interaction: ].
Postcondition: Having had concerns about his patient, Dr Attend has successfully referred Mr. Everyman to Dr. Cutter.
Update Requirements Summary: The actors for this communication are Drs. Attend, Cutter, Dunst and the Quit Now clinic. The foci of the communication are Dr. Attend's health summary and referral request to Dr. Cutter, Dr. Cutter's referral request and inpatient surgical summary sent to Dr. Dunst and the Quit Now clinic.

rmim.name: Care Transfer Request
rmim.descriptive:
Care Transfer Request RMIM Overview
This model captures the data and associations that are needed when a care transfer is requested. This model, and its accompanying diagram, is very similar to the Care Provision DMIM but uses "local CMETs" to abstract the complexity of the care structures associated with the Care Provision Request Act. The reader should refer to the DMIM discussion before reviewing the RMIM followed by the discussion for each care structure. The discussion of this model takes up features that do not explicitly exist in the DMIM, and were not directly addressed in the review of that model. Care Provision Request Focal Class
As noted in the discussion of the DMIM, a Care Provision Request is a request to transfer the responsibility of Care Provision or more simply a Care Transfer Request. Typically the request is made by a clinician within an application and transmitted to the performing party via a messaging interface.
All the participations encountered in this model have already been addressed in the discussion of the DMIM. Associations
The following associations are defined for a Care Provision Request. Each association captures the relationship between the Care Provision Request and an entity or act that plays a significant part in the Care Transfer. Participations
recordTarget: the record target is the entity for which the Care Transfer Request is being recorded. There can only be one record target for a Care Transfer Request. The target entity information is captured within the R_Patient CMET or R_CaredEntity local CMET. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
subject: the subject or subjects that is the target for the care transfer being requested when the subject is not the record target. The subject information is captured within the R_Patient CMET or R_CaredEntity local CMET. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
author: the party that makes the Care Transfer Request. This may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member or court, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
dataEnterer: the transcriptionist who enters the information of the Care Transfer Request. The data enterer information is captured within the R_AssignedPerson CMET.
verifier: the supervisor who verifies the request. There is support for more than one level of verification. The verifying person information is captured within the R_AssignedPerson CMET.
performer: the party who takes part in actually carrying out the requested care provision. There may be multiple performers because several parties may collaborate in the requested care provision. This may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
primaryInformationRecipient: the party who is intended to receive the requested care transfer. This recipient is not the requested performer of the care provision but is receiving the request for their information. This may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member or court, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
Act Relationships
component1: links the Care Provision Request to the care plan that is requested to be performed during the intended patient care provision. Refer to A_CarePlan in the Care Structures topic for further description of this local CMET.
pertinentInformation1: provides pertinent care plans to the care transfer, indicating that these are the other acts that are related but not directly requested as part of the care transfer. Refer to A_CarePlan in the Care Structures topic for further description of this local CMET.
pertinentInformation3: a set of pertinent clinical statements provided as information to support the care transfer. Refer to A_CareStatement in the Care Structures topic for further description of this local CMET.
reason: relationship to a condition recorded as the primary reason for the care transfer. A problem, not specifically a diagnosis, which is the primary reason for the care transfer can also be presented using this relationship. Refer to A_ConditionTrackingEvent in the Care Structures topic for further description of this local CMET.
component2: a collection of clinical statements can be associated as part of the Care Provision Request. This is intended to indicate that, for example, this list of conditions are being managed as part of the requested Care Transfer. Refer to A_StatementCollector in the Care Structures topic for further description of this local CMET.
pertinentInformation2: a Care Transfer Request may have relevant information that is in the form of existing Care Records, which can be attached to the Care Provision Request. Refer to the Care Record topic for further description of this local CMET.
reference: the encounter in which the care transfer was requested, represented by the A_Encounter CMET.
replacementOf: a link to a replaced Care Provision Request. The Care Provision Request being the target of this act relationship has a status of obsolete and can either contain just the instance identifier of the replaced request or the entire request details. NOTE: This relationship should not be used as the Obsolete/Replace Interaction is not currently supported.

rmim.name: Care Transfer Promise
rmim.descriptive:
Care Transfer Promise RMIM Overview
This model captures the data and associations that are needed when a Care Transfer is promised or accepted. CareProvisionPromise Focal Class
A Care Provision Promise is an announcement of the acceptance of taking on the responsibility of Care Provision as stated in the fulfilled request. Typically the assigned person responsible for performing the Care Provision fulfilled by the request is the author of the Care Transfer Promise. It is assumed the request is recorded within an application and transmitted to the performing party via a messaging interface; in which case the promise is sent as a acceptance to that request. Only the minimum information required to promise to fulfill the request is provided in the current model, as it was seen to be not necessary to replicate the request detail in the case where requests were not received electronically.
The Care Transfer Promise RMIM can be used to accept/promise or reject/refuse a previously directed request for care provision. Associations
The following associations are defined for a Care Transfer Promise. Each association captures the relationship between the Care Transfer Promise and an entity or act that plays a significant part in the Care Transfer Promise. Participations
recordTarget: the record target is the entity for which the Care Transfer Promise is being made. There can only be one record target for a Care Transfer Promise. The target entity information is captured within the R_Patient CMET or R_CaredEntity local CMET. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
subject: the subject is the target for which Care Provision Promise is made when the subject is not the record target. The subject information is captured within the R_Patient CMET or R_CaredEntity local CMET. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
author: the provider that makes the Care Transfer Promise to take on the responsibility of Care Provision, who is analogous to a "fulfiller". This may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
dataEnterer: the transcriptionist who enters the information of the Care Transfer Promise. The data enterer information is captured within the R_AssignedPerson CMET.
verifier: the supervisor who verifies the promise. There is support for more than one level of verification. The verifying party information is captured within the R_AssignedPerson CMET.
performer: the provider who is promising to carry out the Care Provision. There may be multiple performers because several parties may collaborate in the responsibility of Care Provision. This may be an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty) such as a healthcare provider, a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description.
primaryInformationRecipient: the provider who is intended to receive the acceptance of the Care Transfer. The recipient is usually the author of the associated care transfer request, which may be represented by an assigned person or organization (R_AssignedParty), a related party (R_RelatedParty) such as a family member or court, or the patient (R_Patient) themselves. Refer to the respective CMETs for further description. Act Relationships
InFulfillmentOf: a Care Transfer Promise is associated with the Care Transfer Request being accepted, that is the Care Transfer Request that the promise fulfills. Only the id attribute is provided to link the request to the promise.
ReplacementOf: a link to a replaced Care Transfer Promise. The Care Transfer Promise being the target of this act relationship has a status of obsolete and can either contain just the unique identifier of the replaced promise or its entire details.

interaction.name: Care Transfer Request Activate Fulfillment Request

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The interaction is used to request the receiver accept responsibility for care provision of the subject. The interaction has two possible receiver responsibility types. The first, Care Transfer Promise, is used by the receiving application role when it accepts the request. The second receiver responsibility is Reject Care Transfer and is used by the fulfiller to reject the request.

descriptive.name: Reason
descriptive.p: The fulfiller does not agree to perform the request.

descriptive.name: Reason
descriptive.p: The fulfiller agrees to perform the request.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The interaction notifies a receiver that a sender has requested a healthcare provider to take on the responsibility for care for a subject and that the requested care transfer has been activated and is awaiting fulfillment.

descriptive.name: Reason
descriptive.p: The fulfiller has completed the responsibility of care provision in fulfillment of request. The fulfiller uses this when it wishes to acknowledge a request with the care transfer being requested.

rcvrresp.name: Responsibility- 2
rcvrresp.descriptive: The fulfiller does not agree to perform the request

descriptive.name: Reason
descriptive.p: The fulfiller agrees to perform the request

descriptive.name: Reason
descriptive.p: The fulfiller has begun the responsibility of care provision in fulfillment of the request. The fulfiller uses this when it wishes to acknowledge a request with the care transfer being requested.

interaction.name: Care Transfer Request Revise Fulfillment Request

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: The interaction is used to request the receiver to accept a revision of a previously accepted responsibility of care the subject. The interaction has two possible receiver responsibility types. The first, Care Transfer Promise is used by the receiving application role when it accepts the revised request. The second receiver responsibility is Reject Care Transfer and is used by the fulfiller to reject the revised request.

descriptive.name: Reason
descriptive.p: The fulfiller does not or cannot accept the revised care transfer request.

rcvrresp.name: Responsibility- 2
rcvrresp.descriptive: The fulfiller has not yet promised to accept the care transfer request that is being revised, but now accepts the revised care transfer request.

rcvrresp.name: Responsibility- 3
rcvrresp.descriptive: The fulfiller accepts the replaced care transfer request.

teref.refName: Care Transfer Promise Obsolete Confirmation Replace

interaction.name: Care Transfer Request Revise

subdivn.name: Allergies & Intolerance Topic
subdivn.descriptive:
Scope and Use Cases
Allergy and Intolerance observations are some of the most commonly recorded, reviewed and transmitted information in the medical record. Clinicians record allergies and intolerances as a way to remind themselves and other providers to avoid giving substances that are known to potentially cause harm or discomfort to the patient. The process of identifying known adverse reactions and the believed causes for them is a critical element of good clinical practice and is essential for safety and quality (Nehta). Within the context of allergies, adverse reactions are harmful or undesirable responses after administration of an agent/substance. Intolerance is a condition where the patient has been noted to have an adverse reaction and a judgment is made that the reaction was caused by a given substance. Administration of substances (in the form of ingestion, inhalation, injection, or direct contact) may result in adverse reactions which may be classified as severe or mild, occur after variable lengths of time, and the relationship between exposure and the adverse reaction may be uncertain. Additionally, the noted exposure may be (usually is) to a mixture of complex substances. Additionally, many substances cross react, so that it may be a class of medications that cause problems. Therefore the assignment of causality of the actual relationship between the offending substance and the reaction is generally always uncertain to some degree.
Use Case 1: The clinical "Allergy" list: Many make the distinction between a true allergy and intolerance. A true allergy is a type of intolerance with where the patient's immune system "hyper" reacts after exposure to that agent/substance or a chemically similar substance. True allergies typically result in a rash or swelling and may be life threatening. They also have defined treatments such as steroids antihistamines, or epinephrine. The classic example of this is the typical penicillin allergy. Pragmatically, both true allergies and intolerances are recorded in a separate section of the medical record. Although this section is often (usually) called "the allergy list" it more accurately represents a list of "intolerances" or "alerts" since it mixes true allergies and intolerances. Different providers will have varying opinions on the need to specifically note minor intolerances to medications such as gastric upset in this section, however there is general agreement that true allergies and severe intolerances be recorded in this section and reviewed regularly. Some severe intolerances such as heparin induced thrombocytopenia do not follow the same physiologic pathways as true allergy but follow the same need for explicit and clear warning to prescribing or administrating providers and therefore are grouped in with "allergies." Fortunately, the modeling for allergies and intolerances for this purpose does not need to include details of pathogenesis to this degree, so this mixing while technically inaccurate is of little consequence. Logically, an allergy or intolerance is a type of medical condition or concern. It is an observation (as judged by the clinician) that asserts the patient does or does not have a condition where a substance administration is felt to be associated with an adverse reaction. It may tracked like other medical concerns as a series of observations as further clarification or understanding of the nature of that allergy occurs. For example, an observation of an allergy to percocet may be refined to a mild intolerance to "oxycodone", but tracked separately from the concern about allergy beta-lactams being refined to exclude cephalosporins. However, there are important distinctions between most medical concerns and allergies concerns. Because they are used as specific reminders not to administer or to alter therapy, they are generally called out as a separately tracked list. Other clinical conditions and patient data may also alter therapy as well (for example dose changes based on age or renal function, or contraindications to medications in certain medical conditions) but allergies are differentiated because they are recorded as the type of therapy to avoid rather than as conditions which usually can't be avoided. Also, in many cases systems may require explicit review and specific negative assertions for various types of known allergens. For example, it is most common to see a section of a document or element of the EMR which explicitly states that the patient does not have any known allergies or any known drug allergies. The degree of granularity for specific negation is variable from specific application to application or from use case to use case. For example, many systems record explicitly that the patient is NOT allergic to Latex or IV contrast. In general, obviously harmful substance administrations such as poisoning or overdoses are not included in allergy/intolerance lists because there should never be such an intent to treat the patient in such a manor. Similarly, seasonal or pet allergies which share many of the same underlying pathophysiology as true allergy are typically not recorded in allergy lists because there is generally not concern that these substances will be administered as therapy planning. This is not absolute, however as some physicians do prefer to track environmental allergies in this section. Food allergies on the other hand, generally are included in this list since diets may be ordered or prescribed and many medications or immunizations may include food substances, however. Most notably many immunizations are grown in eggs. Data Capture: Allergies/Intolerance lists are typically reviewed at many points of patient care. For example, physicians typically review patient allergies when they first see a patient or perform History and Physicals. Nurses typically have a similar intake assessment where allergies are reviewed as do pharmacists. Typical use patterns typically involve a review rather than capture of new allergies because allergy information is considered to be important by a wide variety of people and so it is frequent that some records are available which provide this information. For example, a nurse may review a list of the patients allergies from transfer records when he/she does their intake assessment, and a physician may review the nurses list with the patient when he/she does their history and physical. It is also common that allergy lists are reviewed and updated in the course of care when new information is available. For example, it may be noted that the patient has a new suspect allergy when noted to have an adverse reaction after exposure to a medication. Similarly there is often review and correction a result of need to challenge the certainty that the allergy exists. For example an allergy to Penicillin may be noted. This may persist for quite some time before the patient actually needs antibiotics, and further questioning may reveal that the reaction happened many years ago and that patient is unsure about specifically what happened. Cautious trials of therapy or even further verification testing may proceed as a result. Additional clarification details may be appended such as "patient has tolerated cephalosporins in the past" (i.e. cross reactivity has been ruled out) or the allergy may even be marked as erroneous. Allergies and some intolerances may be supported by evidence such as allergy sensitivity testing or serology tests.
Data Use: Allergy information is useful for a variety of use cases. First, and importantly, it is used in the simple human review of allergy information. Patients may forget or may be unable to indicate allergy information. Indeed, even the same provider may have difficulty remembering a patients allergies as the patient moves through the continuity of care. As a result, allergy information is usually provided from provider to provider on any patient transfer of care, discharge, or referral. This occurs through paper documents, simple storage in an EMR where both clinicians share the same EMR, or exchange between clinical information systems when the clinicians use different systems. Electronic transfer of this information may be either through structured documents, messages, or queries depending on particular use cases and or system capabilities. Allergy data always includes some representation of the allergen, however also should ideally include the reaction with or without severity. It may include additional details including when the event occurred or supporting details. The data capture is often incomplete, however, and even the allergen may be at a hazy level of granularity. For example, the patient may only remember that they are allergic to a "-cillins" (several different types of antibiotics) Allergy information needs to be codified and computer processable since many systems use and exchange allergy data for the expressed purpose of drug order to allergy checks, and may require allergy information to be assessed. Many systems also require statements about the status allergy review within a given time period, thus it is important to include even updates even when the assertion is simply to repeat that no allergies are known to exist. In some cases allergy information is used for reporting to external agencies.
Walk-Through
This is a walk through of a generic allergy/intolerance model, which can be constrained to record and list a patient's allergy or intolerances to various levels of agent/substance hierarchy, as well as to more generic concepts such as food and the environment. The model depicts the three major components of the Allergy/Intolerance structure, namely:
Allergy/Intolerance List
Allergy/Intolerance Summary Observation
Allergy/Intolerance Concern
These component parts of the allergy/intolerance structure will be described in detail here, beginning with the core Act classes. The definitions for class attributes are available in Reference Information Model (RIM) documentation and will not be repeated here.
Allergy/Intolerance Core Act Classes
AllergyIntoleranceList - REPC_RM000322UV
This RMIM is used to create a list from allergy/intolerance detail observation (tracked as allergy concerns) and allergy/intolerance summary observations. Different providers may use this RMIM to create a list of allergies and intolerances for different custodians/owners.
Attributes
Code (Allergy/Intolerance Type): This is a mandatory code that lists the allergy/intolerance(s) and is constructed from allergy/intolerance concerns and allergy/intolerance summary.
Participations
Informant (Provider or Patient or Related Party): In the case where the information in the record is being captured second-hand, this identifies the source of the information. Understanding the source of data is essential to its interpretation. If not specified, it is assumed that the author is capturing information of which they have first-hand awareness.
recordTarget1 (Patient): This identifies the patient associated with the allergy/intolerance record.
author1 (Provider): This identifies the provider who is responsible for the decision to capture the Allergy/Intolerance in the patient's EHR. Used to identify responsibility for accuracy and relevance of the information.
responsibleParty (Provider): Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author, usually a supervisor. Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
location: Indicates the service delivery location where the allergy was recorded. Indicates where records are likely kept for follow-up. May also be useful in understanding the context in which the allergy/intolerance was recorded.
custodian: Constitutes the owner of the list.
Act Relationships
component: Has 'component' relationship to the AllergyIntolerancConcern class, indicating that the allergy/intolerance concerns do contribute to the creation of the allergy/intolerance list.Component1: Has 'component' relationship to the AllergyIntolerancSummaryObservation class, indicating that the allergy/intolerance summary observations contribute to the creation of the allergy/intolerance list.
AllergyIntoleranceSummaryObservation - REPC_MT000323UV
This class is employed by a provider to assert that a patient has no known allergy or intolerance whatsoever, or that the patient has no known allergy or intolerance to any generic concept of an agent/substance such as Drug, Food, etc.
This recording of 'No Known Indicator' is not a derivation from the absence of allergy/intolerance concern; instead, it is recorded as an explicit assertion based on the provider making the necessary assessment. It is about the fact that the list contains no concerns of a particular type.
The only reason for needing this class, is to be able to assert a 'No Known ...' observation without tying it to a 'Concern', i.e. so as not to raise a concern just to be able to say that there is no concern.
Attributes
code (Allergy or Intolerance): This is a mandatory that indicates that the summary assertion is in reference to an allergy or intolerance.
negationInd (No Known Indicator): This is a mandatory attribute whose value is fixed to 'true', indicating that this class is used to make negative assertions (assertion of non-existence of an allergy/intolerance concern) only.
value (Type of Allergy or Intolerance Summary): This is a mandatory whose domain indicates the generic class of concepts for which negative assertion is being made. Include the codes for Allergy (negated as: No Known Allergy), Intolerance (negated as: No Known Intolerances), Drug (negated as: No Known Drug Allergy), Food (negated as: No Known Food Allergy), etc
Participations
Participants in this class are: author (Provider), responsibleParty (Supervisor), subject2 (Patient), informant (Provider, or Patient, or Related Party), participant, and location. For full descriptions of these participants, please refer to the 'Participations' section for the AllergyIntoleranceList class.
Act Relationships
The only actRelationship from this class is to serve as a source for allergy/intolerance problem list as compiled by the AllergyIntoleranceList class.
AllergyIntoleranceConcern - REPC_RM000324UV
This class is used to track a patient's allergy or intolerance to a specific agent or substance, as observed by various providers at various points in time and locations. The name and nature of the concern is derived from the first allergy/intolerance observation made for the agent/substance, which could be an indication of a negative assertion for an allergy or intolerance to an agent/substance (e.g. Patient is not allergic to penicillin).
Attributes
Id (Concern Identifier): A mandatory attribute for uniquely identifying the particular allergy/intolerance concern. Allows on-going observations made on the same initial problem to be tracked as the same concern.
statusCode (Concern Status): Used to summarize the status of the specific allergy/intolerance as indicated by the last observation made on the allergy or intolerance. For full description of the various statuses of a Concern, please refer to the Concern Tracker CMET: REPC_RM000300UV A_ConcernTracking
effectiveTime (Time concern started and ended): Used to summarize the period of the concern, based on the information contained in the first and last allergy/intolerance observations made.
confidentialityCode: Used to assign privacy to the particular allergy/intolerance concern.
Participations
Participants in this class are: author (Provider), responsibleParty (Supervisor), subject2 (Patient), informant (Provider, or Patient, or Related Party), participant, and location. For full descriptions of these participants, please refer to the 'Participations' section for the AllergyIntoleranceList class.
Act Relationships
subject: Has 'subject' relationship to the AllergyIntoleranceObservation class, indicating that the allergy concern is the subject of one or more allergy or intolerance observations.
For full descriptions of the actRelationships, please refer to the 'Act Relationship' section for the generic PC Concern Tracking CMET: REPC_RM000300UV - A_ConcernTracking. The four main actRelationships of interest are employed to achieve the following:
replacing an existing concern with a new one
linking a concern to another concern
making a concern a sub-concern of another concern
specifying an existing in various sequel relationships to another concern.
Other classes
The following is a brief description of other classes that are defined as part of the AllergyIntoleranceConcern structure:
ControlActEvent: This class provides the ability to manage/indicate the state transitions of an allergy/intolerance concern, including the ability to indicate 'resolution' (i.e. the allergy or intolerance had been resolved, and was no longer a concern).
AllergyIntoleranceDetailObservation
The AllergyIntoleranceDetailObservation structure comprises a collection of classes including Observation, Substance Administration, and Control Acts. It also includes modeling of materials and numerous Act Relationships. These will be described in detail here, beginning with the core Act classes. The definitions for class attributes are available in Reference Information Model (RIM) documentation and will not be repeated here.
Attributes
Id (Allergy or Intolerance Identifier): Identifies unique occurrence of an allergy or intolerance observation record.
code (Allergy or Intolerance): Indicates that the object of the observation is to record an allergy or an intolerance concern in the patient's EHR.
negationInd: Used to assert that a patient is, or is not allergic/intolerant to the agent in question. The negationInd attribute is set to 'false' when recording that a patient has allergy or intolerance to the agent/substance in question; whereas it is set to 'true' when asserting that a patient has no allergy or intolerance to the agent/substance.
statusCode: Has fixed status of 'completed', indicating a point in time observation that is not updateable.
value (Type of Allergy/Intolerance): This has either a coded value or a null flavor of 'N/A'. If recording as a code/value, the code should have the semantic of 'allergy to xxx'. If recording the allergy to an agent through the 'participant', then the value should have a null flavor.
methodCode: Indicates the provider's overall causality assessment and cognitive procedure for asserting that the patient is, or is not allergic or intolerant to the agent in question.
Participations
participant: Identifies the exposed agent (medication or a generic administrable material) that is believed to have triggered the allergy or intolerance. This participation must not be specified if the value attribute of the focal class has a valid code with appropriate semantic. On the other hand, this participation must be specified if the value attribute of the focal class has a null flavor of 'N/A'
Other participants in this class are: author (Provider), responsibleParty (Supervisor), subject2 (Patient), informant (Provider, or Patient, or Related Party), participant, and location. For full descriptions of these other participants, please refer to the 'Participations' section for the AllergyIntoleranceList class.
Act Relationships
subject: Indicates a particular type of reaction experienced by the patient which provides evidence for the existence (or non-existence) of the allergy/intolerance. May help ascertain the severity of the condition, and provide direction for management.
subjectOf2: Indicates the gravity of the patient's allergy or intolerance to the agent or the gravity of the patient's reaction to the agent.
subjectOf1: Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy/intolerance.
support: Points to result of a previously conducted allergy test that supports or refutes the allergy/intolerance observation. Provides evidence for recording the allergy or intolerance.
Other Classes
The following is a brief description of other classes that are defined as part of the AllergyIntoleranceObservation structure:
Reaction: This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance. This aids providers in distinguishing between proper allergies and non-allergy intolerances, and allows the provider recording the allergy/intolerance to assign appropriate severity to the allergy/allergy record.
SubstanceAdministration: Incidence of the patient's exposure to some substance (medication, food, etc) through administration that might have caused the reaction.
SeverityObservation: Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient. Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed.
Annotation: This is a list of comments made about the record by providers. Information captured here includes the provider making the comments; and excludes information that would render the record invalid. Allows various Providers to attach comments to an existing record, and thus improving cross-provider communications.
AllergyTestEvent: Indicates the specific allergy test that supports the recording of the allergy/intolerance. Provides evidence for recording the allergy/intolerance in the patient's EHR.
