descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the recording of a food allergy and the need to harmonize with CDA.

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Patient Report Food Allergy
descriptive.p: Precondition: On evaluation in Dr. Cultures office, Mr. Everyman is queried about the rash, and it is found that the rash occurred after eating peanut oil, which Mr. Everyman forgot to report as a known childhood allergy.

Activities: Dr. Culture updates the allergy list to reflect the food allergy to peanut oil. He references the previously recorded rash as the reaction and records this information in a CDA consult note back to Dr. Primary. Dr. Primary imports the allergy data from the note into his EMR.
Post-condition: The food allergy is recorded.

story.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Adds Allergy Information

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate a physician adding Allergy information to a patient record. This information is shared with other providers.

story.descriptive:
Precondition: Patient Adam Everyman is seeing Dr. Patricia Primary for evaluation of a cough. In the process of recording Mr. Everyman's history Dr. Primary states a history of no known drug allergies (NKDA). After reviewing Mr. Everyman's history and exam findings, Dr. Primary decides that Mr. Everyman probably has chronic bronchitis and should be referred to the pulmonologist Dr. Bob Breathright for further evaluation.
Activities: Dr Primary creates an electronic referral letter which includes the allergy information embedded in the document. He sends this data to Dr. Breathright as part of the electronic referral documents. Alternative flows include Dr. Primary posts documents or the allergy information to a central repository and Dr. Breathright queries the repository. Other flows might have Dr. Breathright query Dr. Primary's EMR directly.
PostConditions: Dr. Breathright accepts the referral and has the relevant allergy information.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to show the need to annotate allergies with further test results (e.g. with skin testing) as evidence, and to correct prior allergy assumptions, where the allergy is refuted.

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Annotates Allergy
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Everyman is subsequently noted to have Endocarditis with cultures growing Enterococcus. Dr. Ida D. Culture, the Infectious Disease consultant is called onto the case. Dr. Culture suggests that Penicillin skin testing be performed since it is much more effective than alternative agents.

Activities: Skin testing is performed which shows that Mr. Everyman is NOT allergic to penicillin after all. Dr. Culture records the correction to the allergy list. The updated information is shared with the pharmacy system.
Post-condition: The allergy list reflects no known drug allergies (NKDA) and the penicillin allergy is explicitly negated.

story.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Clarifies Allergy Information
story.descriptive: The purpose of this storyboard is to clarify allergy information and the use of allergy information for drug/allergy checking. Allergens may cross react, therefore allergy information may require annotations that clarify the nature and scope of the allergy. Furthermore updates to allergy information is synchronized between multiple hospital systems.

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Clarifies Allergy Information
descriptive.p: Preconditions: Mr. Everyman has been admitted to the hospital and has had a single dose of antibiotics in the emergency room. Dr. Primary has written for Levofloxicin as an alternative to the standard formulary choice of Cefuroxime. Cefuroxime is a type of Cephalosporin. Cephalosporins generally have about a 10% cross reactivity with Penicillin. Culture results later show that the organism in Mr. Everyman's sputum sample are growing Staphalococcus which is resistant to Levofloxicin, but sensitive to Cefuroxime. Dr. Primary asks Mr. Everyman more about the nature of his penicillin allergy. Mr. Everyman admits that he has had other Cephalosporins in the past without any problem.

Activities: Dr. Primary discontinues the order for Levofloxicin, and adds an order for Cefuroxime. The system generates an alert indicating that there is a known cross reactivity between Cefuroxime and penicillin. Dr. Primary overrides the alert and adds an annotation about the fact that Mr. Everyman has tolerated other cephalosporins in the past without difficulty. The updated allergy information is transmitted to the pharmacy system. On reviewing the order, Dr. Drew Drugger, the pharmacist sees the annotation about cephalosporins.
Post condition: The system places the order, and also updates the pharmacy system. The allergies in both systems are updated to reflect the comment that cephalosporins are OK.

story.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Enters Suspect Environmental Allergy

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to demonstrate the linking of information in assessing a response to an allergy, and highlights the need to record the level of certainty, and reuse allergy information in related parts of a modular EMR such as a separate documentation solution. This storyboard refers to .

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Enters Suspect Environmental Allergy
descriptive.p: Precondition: Dr. Primary is viewing the EMR of Patient Everyman. Mr. Everyman has come to clinic to have a rash evaluated. The allergy list records the peanut oil food allergy but "NKDA" (no known drug allergies) and "NKEA" (no known environmental allergies).

Activities: Dr. Primary elicits the patient history. The patient has visited an Indian restaurant for the first time and was exposed to many new spices. The patient wonders whether the rash is due to the spices. Dr. Primary examines the rash and notices the typical linear pattern associated with a plant exposure. She questions the patient further and finds the patient had been working in the garden earlier in the week. The patient has never had cedar wood chips. Dr. Primary assures the patient that allergy to Indian spices is unlikely to be the cause of this rash. Rather, Dr. Primary identifies probable cedar wood chips and educates the patient on the disease. She places the problem "rash - probably due to cedar wood chips" on his problem list and gives the patient a prescription for Prednisone. She adds cedar wood chips to the allergy list with a certainty level of "probable" linking the problem as evidence. Dr. Primary dictates a note of the event. The transcription system accepts a feed including the allergy data.

Post-condition: Mr. Everyman has progress notes, findings, impressions, care plans, and a populated allergy list in the EMR that are captured in a manner that allows navigation from one related data item to the next. Specifically, the user is able to navigate from the current name of the allergy on the allergy list to the string of observations and treatment activities associated with management of that allergy over time. Additionally, the user is able to navigate from a data item to the allergy management programs supported by the data element.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to demonstrate the flow of information in tracking an allergy and highlighting the need to record reaction severity.

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Notes Severe Intolerance
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Everyman is bitten by a bee in his back yard. A few hours later he notices that his face and lips are swollen. He feels generally unwell so proceeds to the Emergency room. In the emergency room he develops low blood pressure and shortness of breath. Dr. Eric Rescue, the emergency room physician diagnoses anaphylaxis due to a bee sting, and begins appropriate treatment.
Activities: Dr. Rescue records the problem "Anaphylaxis secondary to Bee sting" in the Problem List and "Bee's" in the allergy list, with a reaction of "anaphylaxis", and a severity of "severe"

Post-Conditions: Dr. Primary follows up with the patient to track problem of Bee allergy tracked on his problem list and prescribes an epinephrine pen, and also keeps the bee allergy on the allergy list.

story.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Reviews Verifies Allergy Information

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate the communication flow in reviewing and confirming allergy information, ensuring the hospital information system and pharmacy system has correct and updated information that is synchronized.

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Reviews Verifies Allergy Information
descriptive.p: Precondition: Mr. Everyman calls Dr. Primary with complaint that he has a fever and is coughing copious amounts of sputum, mostly green in color but sometimes including streaks of blood. Dr. Primary advises Mr. Everyman to go to the Emergency Room for evaluation.

Activities: Dr. Primary prepares an emergency department referral which includes allergy information as it's recorded in his EMR. In the emergency room, Nurse Carrie Careful reviews allergies with Mr. Everyman. Mr. Everyman is coughing severely and finds it hard to speak without coughing. The history goes a little faster because she has seen the referral note from Dr. Primary that includes the penicillin allergy. She quickly confirms this with Mr. Everyman with the statement "I see from your records that you have an allergy to penicillin, is that correct?" Mr. Everyman nods, yes. She asks about other allergies to which Mr. Everyman nods, no. She notes the Penicillin Allergy in her nurse assessment. The system prompts explicitly for Latex and IV contrast. She reviews these with Mr. Everyman, who again nods no. She records "no latex allergy" "no IV contrast allergy". Dr. Eric Rescue, the physician on call in the emergency department, also reads Nurse Careful's assessment and confirms this with Mr. Everyman. Dr. Rescue decides Mr. Everyman has pneumonia and needs to be admitted. Dr. Rescue verifies the penicillin allergy in his note and prescribes Levaquin. Orders and Allergy information are sent to the hospital pharmacy system.

Post Condition: Drugs that might cause adverse reactions are avoided by the system alerts. The hospital information system has a correct and updated allergy list and this is shared with the pharmacy system. Verification that the patient does not have IV and latex allergies is recorded.

descriptive.name: Purpose
descriptive.p: The purpose of this storyboard is to illustrate a specialist updating allergy information and notifying Dr. Primary so appropriate updating of his system can occur.

descriptive.name: Allergyintolerance Physician Updates Allergy Information
descriptive.p: Precondition: Dr. Breathright, a pulmonologist is seeing Mr. Everyman in his office after a referral from Dr. Primary. Dr. Breathright reviews the allergy information with Mr. Everyman noting the prior assessment of no known drug allergies (NKDA) from Dr. Primary. On review, Mr. Everyman recalls that he failed to mention an allergy to Penicillin. Mr. Everyman cannot recall what reaction happened, only that his mom told him as a child not to take it.

Activities: Dr. Breathright records the updated allergy to penicillin in his EMR. He includes this information in his consult note back to Dr. Primary. Alternative flows include Dr. Primary receiving message of the updated allergy information via message sent either directly, or forwarded from the central repository.
Post condition: Dr. Primary receives notification of the updated allergy information, and can update his system appropriately.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: A new or updated allergy list is recorded, and request is made to update another system. This notification requires confirmation of the update by the receiving system. The entire list is sent.

descriptive.p: A request to record an allergy or intolerance in a patient's record has been refused. (E.g. contraindication, patient not found, etc.)

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: A request to modify a previously-recorded allergy or intolerance has been refused (e.g. no permission, patient not found).

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Allergy/Intolerance information is requested.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: Allergy or intolerance data is returned.

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: A new allergy list has been created, or an old allergy list has been updated. This is an unsolicited notification. The entire list and history is included.

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: Professional services deals with the capturing of information about specific activities done "to" a patient such as training, assessments, counseling, physiotherapy and surgery. It excludes activities meant to evaluate a characteristic of a patient (i.e. all observations), though interventions such as colonoscopies which include removal of samples may be classified as professional services. It also excludes the administration of drugs or vaccines, as these are handled by more specialized transactions.

The purpose of the transactions is to capture the discrete encoded data associated with the service such as what was done, where, when, by whom, etc. More specifically this topic covers all transactions related to professional services, including:

list.item: Recording professional services performed, for example education, training, smoking cessation, physiotherapy and surgery for the patient in the EHR.
Retrieving a patient's professional service records - retrieve a list of the professional services performed for a specific patient, potentially filtered by time or other criteria.

descriptive.p: The following is a generic representation of Professional Services:

The interactions are crafted to support a 'request-based' architecture in which messages are sent from a point of service (POS) such as a clinic to a Shared Health Record (SHR). These messages are phrased as requests because the SHR reserves the right to refuse all requests. Reasons might include issues such as lack of permission, lack of recorded patient consent, etc.
Further guidance to the intended usage of these transactions:

list.item: Narrative surgery reports should be handled via the Clinical Observations transactions, see Clinical Document Topic. (Note: Note yet normative and not included in this release.)

item.p: If the patient has had a simple endoscopy or colonoscopy the Record Patient Coded Observation should be used. Common Observations has been incorporated into the Observations Domain. (Note: Note yet normative and not included in this release.)

descriptive.p: This is a walk through of a generic professional service message structure and can be referred to for all the refined message information models.

Note:
The definitions of class attributes are available in the Reference Information Model (RIM) documentation and will not be repeated here.

The Procedure Event act is used to describe all aspects of professional services like the name of healthcare professionals, specific service received and patient details. This central act has relationships to several other acts. Like all patient care RMIMs, most of these relationships connect directly to information pertinent to care provisioning, such as supporting clinical information, comments, referrals, status change information, etc. It also has Participations which define roles of entities, e.g. the role of patient or provider of the service.
The Professional Service focal class is surrounded by the following associations:

list.item: Participation to "ProviderOrPatientOrRelated" choice box (author, performer, responsibleParty, informant, or patient)
Participation to "EHR Repository" (custodian1)
Participation to "Record Location" (custodian2)
Participation to "Service Delivery Location" (location)
The "Has Predecessor" ActRelationship to an Old Procedure Event describing Id of the record it succeeded (predecessor)
The "Has Successor" ActRelationship to a New Procedure Event containing the Id of the succeeding record (successor)
The "Has Subject Of" ActRelationship to Annotation Indicator signifying whether or not there are annotations attached to the professional service record (subjectOf2)
The "Is Component Of" ActRelationship to WorkingListEvent describing category of the service (componentOf1)
The " Subject Of" ActRelationship to DocumentEvent containing the Id of the referenced Service Report (subjectOf3)
The "Is Subject Of" ActRelationship to A_Annotation CMET (subjectOf1) containing comments that have been made about the professional service record
The "Has Reason" ActRelationship to A_SupportingClinicalInformation CMET (reason) containing clinical information to support the need for the service
The "Is Component Of" ActRelationship to A_Encounter CMET indicating the clinicall event group to which this professional service is linked(componentOf2)
The "Is Fulfillment Of" ActRelationship to ActRequest indicating the prior request for which this professional is fulfilling (inFulfillmentOf)

descriptive.p: author (provider): This identifies the provider who is responsible for the decision to capture the Professional Service in the patient's EHR. Note that while the author is frequently the data-enterer, this will not always be the case, for example where transcribers are involved.
performer (Provider): Identifies the person(s) who actually performed the action described in the record.

responsibleParty (Provider): This identifies the person that has primary responsibility for the actions of the author in creating the Professional Service. The supervising provider is not necessarily present when the action is performed, but is professionally accountable for the action through the power to delegate, and the duty to review actions with the performing actor after the fact.
subject (Patient): This identifies the patient associated with the Professional Service record.

informant (Provider, Patient, or RelatedParty): In the case where the information in the record is being captured second-hand, this identifies the source of the information. If not specified, it is assumed that the author is capturing information of which they have first-hand awareness.
custodian1: This indicates the EHR repository the Professional Service record is stored in.

custodian2: This indicates the physical facility where the Professional Service record is stored. This is generally the same as the location where the action was performed, but in some cases may be different. (E.g. where the action was done at the patient's home, but the data is captured and stored in the clinician's clinic. Used to indicate where records are likely kept for follow-up.
location: This identifies the location where the Professional Service actually occurred. E.g. Patient's residence, clinic, work site, etc.

predecessor: Identifies any records that are "superseded" by the current record. This will cause the referenced records to be marked as "obsolete" with a reference pointing to this record. Used in circumstances where information initially captured about an event is erroneous, incomplete or not captured at the desired level of detail and the change cannot be made by retracting the original record

successor: Identifies the record that supersedes the current record. This attribute is set when a new record identifies the current record as being replaced. Used in circumstances where a newer or corrected version of the record of this event exists.

subjectOf2: This association provides an indication that there are notes/comment records associated with the Professional Service record. Used to show whether additional information is available on further drill-down.
subjectOf4: Describes information associated with status change for the professional service record.
componentOf1: Describes the categorization of the service. E.g. Psychological Counseling, Smoking Cessation, Cardiac Surgeries, etc.
subjectOf3: Indicates an identifier for a report associated with the professional service.
subjectOf1: This indicates comments that providers have recorded about the Professional Service.
reason: Identifies the clinical reason(s) for performing the action described by the record. Essential for understanding the context in which the action was performed.

component2: This identifies the encounter-based, condition-based and/or other care-based collections that the Professional Service is considered to be part of. Care compositions (defined by A_CaredEntity CMET) provide a means of navigating a patient's EHR by grouping related records together into identified "collections"".

inFulfillmentOf: This ties the record to the request (referral or specific request) that resulted in the creation of the Professional Service record. By requesting the action, a provider takes a level of responsibility for it. Also, a link between request and fulfilling record may result in differences in query responses.

The specific messages defined for the recording or listing of professional services may be slightly constrained versions of the generic professional service structures described above. Following is the list of professional service RMIMs, identifying the those components of the professional service generic structure that have been constrained out:
REPC_RM610001 - Professional Service Record

This is the message payload for recording professional service for the first time. Thus, the following is a list of deviations from the full complement of professional service structure as described above:

list.item: Service Record Id (ProcedureEvent.Id) is not specified
Author and ResponsibleParty participations are constrained out (sent in message as part of ControlActWrapper)
The 'Replaced by Record' class is not specified
Cardinality of the subjectOf1 actRelationship is set to [0..1]
Service Category (WorkingListEvent) is not specified

descriptive.p: REPC_RM610002 - Professional Service List

This is the message payload for a response to a query for a patient's professional service summary information. This message comprises the full complement of classes, association, participations and attributes as described above for the generic Professional Service message structure.
REPC_RM610004 - Professional Service List Query

This is not a constrained version of the generic Professional Service message structure. Rather, it is a message that identifies the various parameters that act as filters on the records to be retrieved. Allows the user and/or the point-of-service application to constrain what Professional Service information they wish to retrieve.

descriptive.name: Introduction
descriptive.p: This domain uses "internal" CMETs (as opposed to the universal COCT variety) to provide reuse of model elements within the domain. In the current DSTU release, there are two of these internal CMETs that are not yet normative (or DSTU), but which are included as references in designs that are part of the DSTU. This topic serves as the place-holder for these two CMETs.

rmim.name: Nonstdcmets Event Create
rmim.descriptive:
Care Plan Structure Overview:
Among the most important Care Structures in the Care Provision Domain is the Care Plan Structure. The purpose of this structure is to define the management action plans for the various conditions identified for the target of care. It is the structure in which the care planning for all individual professions or for groups of professionals can be organized, planned and checked for completion. Communicating explicitly documented and planned actions and goals greatly aids the team in understanding and coordinating the actions that need to be performed for the person. Care plans also permit the monitoring and flagging of unperformed activities and unmet goals for later follow up.
The term Patient Care Planning in MESH is described as:
Usually a written medical and nursing care program designed for a particular patient. Year introduced: 1968"
The basic theory underlying this structure comes from Larry Weeds Problem-oriented Medical Record, also introduced in the 1960s, which is used by many health professions and electronic health record systems as a primary method for organizing work and documentation.Phases of Care Plans and Guidelines: Essential to many Care Plans and Guidelines is the concept of sequential "Phases" or stages. These phases of the Care Plan are to be modeled using recursive component ActRelationship on the focal act of Care Provision. Each component phase is then considered a mini-guideline or mini-care plan. Typical phases include those defined by nursing practice, e.g. assessment, plan, performance and evaluation; or those defined by organizational practice, e.g. pre-operative, operative, post-operative recovery, post-operative rehabilitation, etc. (see Figure 1) The decision support tools discussed below govern entrance and exit logic from these mini-guidelines and care plans.
Figure 1 The Care Plan builds upon the collection of Observations that are expressed in the Care Statement structure and usually are organized in the Statement Collector, both structures of the Care Provision D-MIM. Following one to many observations a clinician will determine a diagnoses and from there can set outcomes, define care activities and implement these. Outcomes can be observed at any point during the care.
Link to wide graphic (opens in a new window)
Figure 2. Figure 2 below describes the dynamics of the care process, which is usually documented in the care record. To support the documentation of each of the components of the care process and to facilitate the exchange of data, the HL7 v3 Care Plan structure REPC_RM000200 has been developed. Link to wide graphic (open in a new window)
Care Process. (Goossen W, Ozbolt J, Coenen A, Park HA, Mead C, Ehnfors M, Marin H. (2004). Development of a provisional domain model for the nursing process for use within the Health Level 7 RIM. J Am Med Inform Assoc., 11 (3): 186-194. http://www.jamia.org/cgi/content/short/M1085v1). Scope of Responsibility:
The Care Provision Structure is attached to the Care Provision Act in two ways. As components of the Care Provision Act, the Care Plans reflect part of the scope of responsibility (a component of the care delivery) defined by the Care Provision Act (see the Care Provision Domain narrative). Component is more specific than pertinent. It says that one act is part of another act. In this case, planning for future care is "part of" the delivery of care, which is the focal class. As pertinent information to the Care Provision Act, the Care Plans are used by the receiver to make sure that orders are checked for interactions and not duplicated or mistakenly discontinued by the receiver.
For example, if a request is made to a receiver to answer a particular question on the care of a particular disease, that question may be expressed within a Care Plan request. A particular question may be asked of the receiver of the request to fill in the observation.value field and/or the observation.text field or other relevant fields in an instance of observation. To further illustrate this example; the patient may have a cardiac valve replacement and be anti-coagulated on coumadin. The patient may also be pregnant, which is noted as pertinent information. A cardiologist may be asked for the highest acceptable Protime INR value that would limit bleeding in the pregnancy but still give protection for the valve replacement. In this case, the component care plan would identify the cardiac valve replacement as the reason for the care plan. The Care Plan Class instance would be in request mood. The observation.mood would be goal request; the observation.code would code the Protime test; and, as in all requests, the values for the acceptable INR range are not included, indicating that they should be filled in by the cardiologist (see Table 1).
Table 1: Attribute values for class instances in Care Plan Request
Link to wide graphic (opens in a new window)
In addition, the cardiologist may add a schedule of protime tests in proposal mood to the care plan and include recommended medication adjustments for the various INR values that might be obtained from the protime measurements (see the section on Decision Support below). Moods and States of Care Plans and Guidelines: The difference between the Guideline Class and the Care Plan Class is the difference in concept between a Guideline, which is "a general list of actions that are defined to be applied to all appropriate targets of care when certain pre-conditions are met" versus the Care Plan, which is "the specific list of actions that are intended to be applied to a specific target of care." Therefore, the mood code of Guidelines is Definition Mood, and the mood code of Care Plans is Intent Mood and its children moods (See table 2).
Table 2: Children of Intent Mood (link to ActMood file in RIM) Link to wide graphic (opens in a new window)
A Request would be used to ask a consultant to recommend a care plan. Proposal would be used by a consultant recommending a Care Plan. Intent itself would be used to activate a care plan. Care plans may be scheduled in Appointment mood. For each mood, several states are valid, in particular the states of "active" and "completed. The one or more care plan instances in a given communication potentially contain any acts included in the Care Statement Structure.
Typically, a specific Care Plan will have actions added or taken away from the list of actions in a Guideline, often referred to as Care Plan variations. In relationship to clinical pathways, such variations are normally documented in order to measure the variances on populations of patients, which can be used to improve the guidelines. For the purpose of clarity within the Care Plan Structure, variation is defined here as something that is different from a standard (i.e., the Guideline), where variance is a statistical measure of dispersion, or a calculated degree of variation (How much does this patient differ compared to a group of similar patients). Of course the reasons for these Care Plan variations include the presence of co-morbidities, judgments of the clinician, non-consent of a patient, and other reasons described in the disease management literature.
Often, in a Care Provision communication, the Guideline is named simply as a reference to an external guideline without specifically representing all the Care Statements implied by the Guideline. However, other business needs may require that all the Care Statements that exist in a specific Guideline definition be specifically communicated as well. It should go without saying that in a Care Provision communication, the Care Statements collected by a Guideline need to be kept completely separate for patient safety reasons from Care Statements collected by a Care Plan. However, it is important to be able to document the variation between what the Guideline (in Definition Mood) states should be done, and what according to the Care Statements has actually been done (Any Act in Event Mood). In the Care Plan RMIM, what "has been done" is documented in the "fulfillment" ActRelationship from Care Statements CMET to the Care Plan choice box.Additional Classes: Participations follow the general model for Care Provision Domain as a whole. Reason for the Care Plan is represented by the Reason ActRelationship associated to the disease Condition. Goals and the other Predicate moods (Event.Criterion and Option) may be applied to the whole care plan as well as to component phases of the care plan (see Table 3).
Table 3: Predicate Moods (link to ActMood file in RIM)Link to wide graphic (opens in a new window)
Moods and States of Care Plan Components: As mentioned above, Care Plans are collectors of Care Statements. Like the Care Plan itself, these Care Statements collected by the Care Plan will have moods of either Intent or the children of Intent. However, like any Care Statements in the Intent moods, instances of these Care Statements will be created as the Act concept moves through the downstream stages of the business cycle of Acts, e.g. Events. As mentioned above, the Fulfillment ActRelationships to the Care Plan component Acts represents the downstream instances in the Act business cycle.
Between the use of Definition mood in the Guideline Class Components, the Intent moods in the Care Plan Class Components, the Acts in Predicate moods related to the Care Plans and Components, and the Fulfillment Acts, all the options for moodCode can be used in the Care Plan Structure, thus giving an overview on the dynamics of a whole set of (specialized) Acts planned or performed during Care Provision. Clinician thus can track the status of their work carried out on behalf of Patients or other Targets of Care.
Goals in Care Plans: Goals are common within Care Plan phases, and often must be met in order to move a patient from one phase of a Care Plan to another. For example, for a patient to move from the post-operative recovery room to a surgical floor bed, certain vital signs must be stable. Whether these goals are considered met or not met may depend on clinician judgment or on decision support rules stored in Observation.derivationExpr. A typical goal is expressed as an Observation scheduled for some time in the future with a particular value in the observation.value field. For example, a rule may state that the observation of a heart rate between 60 and 100 must be present at the time of discharge from recovery. A Care Plan may identify this heart rate as a goal for 30 minutes after entry to the recovery unit. Order Sets in Care Plans: Order sets can organize and structure complex health care plans into useful units of work for clinicians. An order within an order set can request any clinical activity including referrals (requests for encounters), acts, supplies, procedures and observations among others. Structured observations and goal setting can also be supported from the order set. The sharing of care protocols and regimes authored as phased order sets has a much broader audience for work on error reduction, standardization of care and quality improvement. Order sets in this context can be envisioned as action elements within a care plan, allowing a clinician to organize and request a step in a larger protocol.
Definition of the structure and function of orders and order sets for an implementation-independent EHR referred to as the virtual medical record (vMR) is a central issue in development of interoperable functionality necessary to publicaly published guidelines that may be used by multiple institutions. HL7 Clinical Decision Support Technical Committee is in the process of describing a multi-layered standard that supports the publication and maintenance of order set libraries, the sharing of order sets between collaborating institutions, the structuring of order sets to support effective clinical use, and the interoperation of order sets within advanced clinical guideline support software. Organizations employing this standard would deploy the depth of specification appropriate to their enterprise needs and the capabilities of their clinical systems architecture and performance.
Within a specific phase or order set, the detail of how care is intended to be delivered is expressed. This detail includes the expression of goals and measurements of outcomes after interventions are applied. Order sets specifically include particular sequences of orders and decision support rules, including rules for stopping or revising orders and rules for entering or exiting the current order set in order to enroll the patient in a new phase of the care plan.
Clinical Decision Support Rules in Care Plans: Management of the flow between phases of a care plan is implemented via decision support rules expressed in instances of the observation class.. These rules, in whatever decision support language is used, may be expressed in the Observation.derivationExpr attribute in the observation class included as a component of the current phase of a Care Plan. Typically the rule evaluates current observations on the patient against goals expressed for the current phase of care and determines whether the patient is ready to move on to the next phase of care.
Further guidance on the use of these decision support languages will be published by the HL7 Clinical Decision Support Technical Committee. Examples used in Care Provision models include expressions as simple as formulae for calculations, such as summing up a total score, or as complicated as making a choice between two potential actions based on decision criteria expressed in the derivation expression logic syntax.
Care Plan Structure Walk-through:CarePlan Focal Class:The Care Plan Structure's focal class act represents the care plan.
classCode: The vocabulary domain specified for Act.classCode includes PCPR (Patient Care Provision) as a specialization of the Act class.moodCode: The Care Plan Act may be expressed in many moods. These moods distinguish the different aspects of the business lifecycle of a Care Plan Act. These moods for the Care Plan are defined as follows:
DEF (definition)Definition mood code can be used to express a guideline or protocol. This can include treatment protocols, standardized care plans, clinical pathways or similar.
INT (intent)
Intent can be used to express the intended activities in a care plan. In particular the appropriate selection of observations and activities from a guideline that are included in the care plan for one particular patient. So the intended Acts are individualized from the guideline.
GOL (Goal)
Expectation to make a specific observation with a desired value at a predefined future time.
In the clinical pathway, the goal can be put against the actual value (the observation in event mood). If there is a difference, it is the individual variation of the patient against the goal. If a population of patients is measured against the goal, and the average is calculated, it is the variance.
RQO (request)
A "Care Plan Request" is a question to another care provider regarding their ability to accept the responsibility of a Care Plan for the subject. A Request would be used for instance to ask a consultant to recommend a care plan. The scope of responsibility including CareProvision.code, reasons for care provision, and component care plans that set the specific expectations for care apply to the scope of responsibility for the receiver of the request.
PRP (Proposal)
Proposal would be used by a consultant recommending a Care Plan. Intent itself would be used to activate a care plan. Care plans may be scheduled in Appointment mood.
ActMoodPredicate
Any of the above service moods (e.g., event, intent, or goal) can be turned into a predicate used as a criterion to express conditionals (or queries.) However, currently we allow only criteria on service events.
id: This attribute identifies a particular Care Plan. derivationExpr: The derivation expression attribute allows a string expression on derivation and is supported in an observation instance. It is used in Care Plan to give instructions (Definition mood), or to explain how a value has been determined (event mood). Examples often used include the summing up of individual scores to a sumscore, e.g. for the Apgar score or Barthel index.
title: One title can be given to the Care Plan in free generated text. This can be done in the definition mood to refer to a guideline or pathway, and in the intent mood to refer to a particular care plan for a target. statusCode: The statusCode attribute is used to indicate the current state of the Care Plan. The statusCode attribute corresponds to the Act state machine and for the Care Plan has the following valid values:
Code
Definition
active
The care plan can be performed or is being performed.
suspended
An care plan that has been activated (actions could or have been performed against it), but has been temporarily disabled. No further action should be taken against it until it is resumed.
completed
A care plan that has terminated normally after all of its constituents have been performed.
aborted
The care plan has been terminated prior to the originally indended completion.
obsolete
This care plan has been replaced by a new instance, e.g., due to changes, goals not met etc.
nullify
This care plan was created in error and has been 'removed' and is treated as though it never existed. A record is retained for audit purposes only.
The other attributes have the common Act attributes characteristics that are explained in detail at the D-MIM level. Participations from Care Plan
The Care Plan focal class has several participations to R_AssignedPerson, R_AssignedParty and R_AssignedEntity. These have similar meaning as in the D-MIM and are explained there.
Important here however is that the R_AssignedEntity in the author participation can be the patient her or himself. This for those instances that patients regulate their own treatment and / or care.
Further, the Performer participation uses the functionCode to distinguish between the Care Coordinator and other care team members. We do need new ParticipationFunction code for Care Coordinator. Component Relationship
The component relationship from Care Plan Act to itself functions to phasing the care plan trough the different phases. Guideline Act Relationship
The focal class Care Plan has a Definition relationship to the Guideline Class. The type code of the Act Relationship is INST (instantiates). It is used in the context of the Care Plan to capture the link between the Guideline (the master part) and the actual service, where this is the actual care plan for a particular patient. The instantiation in the Care Plan may override the Guidelines contents via removing, altering or adding to the care plan. Guideline
The Guideline's attributes are similar to the Care Plan except for the mood code which is always in DEF (Definition) and the text attribute that allows to give full written explanations about the guideline, e.g. the scientific evidence for it's use, reference to the literature, and instructions for a professional how to deal with it.
The guideline has an author participation with R_AssignedEntity who is responsible for the content.
The guideline has also a component relationship to link different instances of the guideline together or to link different components from the guideline choice box.
{Future work of PC TC here will include a structure that allows the variation tracking on individual level and variance analysis on population level of of yes / no adhering to Guideline and how. This includes the adding or removing and stating the reason why the change is made.}
Guideline Component Relationship
This kind of relationship has been explained at D-MIM level and is used here in the standard way. A guideline can consist of several components from the Defined Care choice box.
Defined Care choice box.
This choice box holds several of the classes of the Care Statement structure. All instances in the Defined Care Choice Box have the mood code Definition (DEF).
Patient Instructions
This act Patient Instructions holds the relevant instructions for the patient that are derived from or associated with the guideline and the guidelines. The attributes are similar to generic act.
{The class code PROC is subject to change given ongoing discussions on this matter} Final Goal
Via the final ActRelationship the Act Class ObservationGoal is associated to the Care Plan. The function of the ObservationGoal is to set goals in the Care Plan. It works like this: If an Observation at a point in time (that is expressed in a care statement observation) has a particular value, the clinician can state a better value as goal and Plan activities in the Care Plan to achieve the goal and thus to improve the situation for the patient. Alternatively, the Guideline on which the Care Plan can be based can state a reference value for a particular observation and the ObservationGoal can be used to define that in the Care Plan for the individual patient (Target).
In the event mood of this observation (that is then the 2nd instantiation for this observation, where goal is the 1st), the actual value is present and can be compared to the ObservationGoal value. The variation can also be determined, which is a third instantiation of the observation, related to the goal and to the actual value.
PlannedCare Choice Box
The PlannedCare choice box is connected to the Care Plan via a component relationship, indicating that a care plan can have 0 to many components in it.
In the Planned Choice box, all the different Act classes are in Intent mood (INT) to indicate what activities, observations, encounters, and substance administrations, etc. are planned in the Care Plan for an individual.
The PlannedCare choice box has an inFulfillment Act relationship with the Guideline choicebox. This can be used to determine that an act in the PlannedCare choice box fulfills the suggested act in the guideline.
{Future work for the Care Plan will include further expression of the exact mechanics for this relationship, including the explanations for it, and the changes of moods and acts status}. Criterion
The PlannedCare choice box has a act relationship named 'conditions' to the Act Criterion. The function of Criterion is explained in depth elsewhere in the D-MIM. It functions here in a similar way: to set limits and criteria to particular acts. Material
Via the consumable participation the SubstanceAdministrationIntent Act class in the PlannedCare choice box has a direct link to the Role Choicebox Material, in which the roles AdministrableMaterial and Medication can be selected and thus the Entity MaterialKind and via the MaterialPart role to MaterialKind2. MaterialKind is constrained to class codes PART or INGR (ingredient) It functions similarly as in the Care Statement and allows to determine in the Care Plan what substance should be given at what time. ConditionTracking
Via the 'reason' relationship the PlannedCare choice box is linked to the ConditionTracking CMET. Care Statement
The Care Statement (as CMET expressed here to link to the whole structure in the R-MIM) is linked to the PlannedCare choice box via the fulfillment relationship. This functions such that the planned care acts in intent mood and the care statement acts that are in event mood are linked to each other.
The moodcode of the Care Statement here is constrained to INT.
ObservationGoal
Similar to the Care Plan Act, the Goal Observation is linked to the PlannedCare choice box (as a shadow). Its function is the same here as described above for Care Plan.
Planned Review
In clinical care, a care plan is reviewed regularly. This can be done on ad hoc basis, e.g. based on changes in the condition of the patient, or when particular observations are present as care statement. However, it is also possible to have a predetermined review of the care plan. For example in elderly care, the care plan will not change very often, but still would require an annual or 6 month review.
The class code is REV for review, the mood is Intent and the effective time is the date of the reassessment. Performer
The AssignedPerson that carries out the acts from the PlannedCare choice box is linked to it via the Performer participation. Annotation
It is possible to add annotations to the Care Plan via the subject of relationship. Annotation in relation to PlannedCare has an Act class code, the EVN moodcode, the text attribute to document the annotation and the statuscode is completed to indicate that the annotation is ready.
Annotation has also an author (shadow from the author of the Care Plan).
Contained Hierarchical Message Descriptions
Care Structures Event Care Plan REPC_HD000200

descriptive.name: Description
descriptive.p: This RMIM is placed here in order to have a refeence anchor for a non-standard CMET - ConditionTrackingEvent. This CMET is referenced in RMIM CareTransferRequest (REPC_RM002000UV). An RMIM design artifact exists for this reference, but no PubDb reference was found and therefore this anchor was created.
